   <h1 id="firstHeading" class="firstHeading" lang="en">Serena Williams</h1> 
   <div id="bodyContent" class="mw-body-content"> 
    <div id="siteSub" class="noprint">
     From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia
    </div> 
    <div id="contentSub"></div> 
    <div id="jump-to-nav"></div> 
    <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#mw-head">Jump to navigation</a> 
    <a class="mw-jump-link" href="#p-search">Jump to search</a>

     <div class="mw-parser-output">
      <div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">
       American tennis player
      </div>

               <td style="text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;"><span class="nowrap"> 2012 London </span></td> 
               <td style="text-align:center;vertical-align:middle;"><a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2012_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_doubles" title="Tennis at the 2012 Summer Olympics – Women's doubles">Doubles</a> </td>

           </div>
          </div></th>
        </tr>
        <tr>
         <td colspan="2" style="text-align:center;font-weight: lighter; color: #555">Last updated on: September 9, 2019.</td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p><b>Serena Jameka Williams</b> (born September 26, 1981)<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_profile_1-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_profile-1">[1]</a></sup> is an American professional tennis player and former world No. 1. She has won 23 <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">major</a> singles titles, most by any man or woman in the <a href="/wiki/Open_Era" class="mw-redirect" title="Open Era">Open Era</a>. The <a href="/wiki/Women%27s_Tennis_Association" title="Women's Tennis Association">Women's Tennis Association</a> (WTA) ranked her world No. 1 in singles on eight separate occasions between 2002 and 2017. She reached the No. 1 ranking for the first time on July 8, 2002. On her sixth occasion, she held the ranking for <a href="/wiki/List_of_WTA_number_1_ranked_tennis_players#Weeks_at_No._1" title="List of WTA number 1 ranked tennis players">186 consecutive weeks</a>, tying the record set by <a href="/wiki/Steffi_Graf" title="Steffi Graf">Steffi Graf</a>. In total, she has been No. 1 for 319 weeks, which ranks <a href="/wiki/Open_Era_tennis_records_%E2%80%93_women%27s_singles" class="mw-redirect" title="Open Era tennis records – women's singles">third in the Open Era</a> among female players behind Graf and <a href="/wiki/Martina_Navratilova" title="Martina Navratilova">Martina Navratilova</a>. </p>
      <p>Williams holds the most <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> titles in singles, doubles, and mixed doubles combined among active players. Her 39 Grand Slam titles put her joint-third on the all-time list and second in the Open Era: 23 in singles, 14 in women's doubles, and two in mixed doubles. She is the most recent female player to have held all four Grand Slam singles titles simultaneously (2002–03 and 2014–15) and the third player to achieve this twice, after <a href="/wiki/Rod_Laver" title="Rod Laver">Rod Laver</a> and Graf. She is also the most recent player to have won a Grand Slam title on each surface (hard, clay and grass) in one calendar year (2015). She is also, together with her older sister <a href="/wiki/Venus_Williams" title="Venus Williams">Venus</a>, the most recent player to have held all four Grand Slam women's doubles titles simultaneously (2009–10). </p>
      <p>Williams has won a record of 13 Grand Slam singles titles on <a href="/wiki/Hardcourt" title="Hardcourt">hard court</a>. Williams holds the Open Era record for most titles won at the <a href="/wiki/Australian_Open" title="Australian Open">Australian Open</a> (7) and shares the Open Era record for most titles won at the <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> with <a href="/wiki/Chris_Evert" title="Chris Evert">Chris Evert</a> (6). She also holds the record for the most women's singles matches won at majors with 349 matches. </p>
      <p>Williams has won 14 Grand Slam doubles titles, all with her sister Venus, and the pair are unbeaten in Grand Slam doubles finals.<sup id="cite_ref-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-4">[4]</a></sup> As a team, she and Venus have the third most women's doubles Grand Slam titles, behind the 18 titles of <a href="/wiki/Natasha_Zvereva" title="Natasha Zvereva">Natasha Zvereva</a> (14 with <a href="/wiki/Gigi_Fern%C3%A1ndez" title="Gigi Fernández">Gigi Fernández</a>) and the record 20 titles won by Martina Navratilova and Pam Shriver. Williams is also a five-time winner of the <a href="/wiki/WTA_Tour_Championships" class="mw-redirect" title="WTA Tour Championships">WTA Tour Championships</a> in the singles division.<sup id="cite_ref-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-5">[5]</a></sup> She has also won four <a href="/wiki/Olympic_medal" title="Olympic medal">Olympic gold medals</a>, one in women's singles and three in women's doubles—an all-time record shared with her sister, Venus.<sup id="cite_ref-CBS-Olympic_6-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBS-Olympic-6">[6]</a></sup> The arrival of the <a href="/wiki/Williams_sisters" title="Williams sisters">Williams sisters</a> has been credited with ushering in a new era of power and athleticism on the women's professional tennis tour.<sup id="cite_ref-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-7">[7]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-8">[8]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-9">[9]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-10">[10]</a></sup> She is <a href="/wiki/WTA_Rankings#Current_rankings" title="WTA Rankings">ranked</a> at No. 9 in the world by the WTA as of September 9, 2019.<sup id="cite_ref-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-11">[11]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Earning almost $29<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>million in prize money and endorsements, Williams was the highest paid female athlete in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12">[12]</a></sup> She repeated this feat in 2017 when she was the only woman on <i><a href="/wiki/Forbes" title="Forbes">Forbes</a></i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span> list of the 100 highest paid athletes with $27<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>million in prize money and endorsements. She has won the 'Laureus Sportswoman of the Year' award four times (2003, 2010, 2016, 2018), and in December 2015, she was named <a href="/wiki/Sports_Illustrated_Sportsman_of_the_Year" class="mw-redirect" title="Sports Illustrated Sportsman of the Year">Sportsperson of the Year</a> by <i><a href="/wiki/Sports_Illustrated" title="Sports Illustrated">Sports Illustrated</a></i> magazine.<sup id="cite_ref-13" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-13">[13]</a></sup> In 2019, she was ranked 63rd in <i>Forbes</i><span class="nowrap" style="padding-left:0.1em;">'</span> World's Highest-Paid Athletes list.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14">[14]</a></sup> </p> 
      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style>

      </div> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life">Early life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=1" title="Edit section: Early life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <p>Williams was born in <a href="/wiki/Saginaw,_Michigan" title="Saginaw, Michigan">Saginaw, Michigan</a>, to <a href="/wiki/Oracene_Price" title="Oracene Price">Oracene Price</a> and <a href="/wiki/Richard_Williams_(tennis_coach)" title="Richard Williams (tennis coach)">Richard Williams</a>, and is the youngest of Price's five daughters: half-sisters <a href="/wiki/Murder_of_Yetunde_Price" title="Murder of Yetunde Price">Yetunde</a>, Lyndrea, and Isha Price, and full older sister <a href="/wiki/Venus_Williams" title="Venus Williams">Venus</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_profile_1-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_profile-1">[1]</a></sup> She also has at least seven paternal half-siblings.<sup id="cite_ref-Edmondson_15-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Edmondson-15">[15]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-16" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-16">[16]</a></sup> When the children were young, the family moved to <a href="/wiki/Compton,_California" title="Compton, California">Compton, California</a>, where Williams started playing tennis at the age of four.<sup id="cite_ref-Serenabio_17-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Serenabio-17">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan200119_18-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan200119-18">[18]</a></sup> Her father home schooled Serena and her sister, Venus.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan200128_19-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan200128-19">[19]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-20">[20]</a></sup> While he and subsequently her mother have been the official coaches, other mentors who helped her learn the game included Richard Williams, a Compton man who shared her father's name and would go on to found The Venus and Serena Williams Tennis/Tutorial Academy.<sup id="cite_ref-Tennis_Week,_March_6,_2006_21-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Tennis_Week,_March_6,_2006-21">[21]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Venus_and_Serena_1993.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Venus_and_Serena_1993.jpg/220px-Venus_and_Serena_1993.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="294" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Venus_and_Serena_1993.jpg/330px-Venus_and_Serena_1993.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/95/Venus_and_Serena_1993.jpg 2x" data-file-width="405" data-file-height="541"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Venus_and_Serena_1993.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Williams sisters at a 
         <a href="/wiki/Pam_Shriver" title="Pam Shriver">Pam Shriver</a> event in Baltimore, 1993
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>When Williams was nine, she and her family moved from Compton to <a href="/wiki/West_Palm_Beach,_Florida" title="West Palm Beach, Florida">West Palm Beach, Florida</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-Serenabio_17-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Serenabio-17">[17]</a></sup> so that she could attend the tennis academy of <a href="/wiki/Rick_Macci" title="Rick Macci">Rick Macci</a>; Macci began to provide additional coaching. Macci did not always agree with Williams's father, but respected that "he treated his daughters like kids, allowed them to be little girls".<sup id="cite_ref-22" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-22">[22]</a></sup> Richard stopped sending his daughters to national junior tennis tournaments when Williams was 10, since he wanted them to go slowly and to focus on school work. Experiences of racism also drove this experience, as Richard Williams had heard white parents talk about the Williams sisters in a derogatory manner during tournaments.<sup id="cite_ref-Newsweek1998_23-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Newsweek1998-23">[23]</a></sup> At that time, Williams had a 46–3 record on the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Tennis_Association" title="United States Tennis Association">United States Tennis Association</a> junior tour and was ranked number one among under-10 players in Florida.<sup id="cite_ref-EdmonsonsEarly_24-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EdmonsonsEarly-24">[24]</a></sup> In 1995, when Williams was in the ninth grade, her father pulled his daughters out of Macci's academy and, from then on, took over all coaching at their home. When asked in 2000 whether having followed the normal path of playing regularly on the junior circuit would have been beneficial, Williams responded: "Everyone does different things. I think for Venus and I, we just attempted a different road, and it worked for us."<sup id="cite_ref-EdmonsonsEarly_24-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-EdmonsonsEarly-24">[24]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Playing_style">Playing style</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=2" title="Edit section: Playing style">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <p>Williams is primarily a <a href="/wiki/Tennis_strategy#Baseliner_strategies" title="Tennis strategy">baseline player</a>, and her game is built around taking immediate control of rallies with her powerful and consistent serve,<sup id="cite_ref-25" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-25">[25]</a></sup> return of serve, and forceful <a href="/wiki/Groundstroke" title="Groundstroke">groundstrokes</a> from both her <a href="/wiki/Forehand" title="Forehand">forehand</a> and <a href="/wiki/Backhand" title="Backhand">backhand</a> swings. Williams's forehand is considered to be among the most powerful shots in the women's game,<sup id="cite_ref-26" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-26">[26]</a></sup> as is her double-handed backhand. Williams strikes her backhand groundstroke using an open stance, and uses the same open stance for her forehand. Williams's aggressive play, a "high risk" style, is balanced in part by her serve, which most say is the greatest in women's tennis history.<sup id="cite_ref-27" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-27">[27]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28">[28]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-29" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-29">[29]</a></sup> She consistently projects great pace and placement with her serves; in the 2013 Australian Open, she had a peak serve speed of 128.6&nbsp;mph (207.0&nbsp;km/h) which is the third fastest all-time among female players (only <a href="/wiki/Venus_Williams" title="Venus Williams">Venus's</a> 129<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>mph<sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-30">[30]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Sabine_Lisicki" title="Sabine Lisicki">Sabine Lisicki</a>'s 131<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>mph<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-31">[31]</a></sup> recorded speeds are faster). What makes her serve even more deadly is her ball placement and her ability to consistently place powerful shots with great accuracy.<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-32">[32]</a></sup> At the 2012 Championships at Wimbledon, she hit a women's tournament record of 102 aces, which was more than any of the men hit during the two weeks, a rarity given that aces are more common in the men's game.<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-33">[33]</a></sup> Williams also possesses a very solid and powerful overhead. Although many think of Williams as only an offensive player,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too-vague attribution or weasel words. (April 2017)">who?</span></a></i>]</sup> she also plays a strong defensive game.<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-34">[34]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-35">[35]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-36">[36]</a></sup> She has stated that her favorite surface is clay because it gives her extra time to set up her shots.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-37">[37]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams is known for producing exceptional comebacks, particularly on the Grand Slam level. She has won three Grand Slam singles titles after saving match points (the 2003 Australian Open semifinal versus <a href="/wiki/Kim_Clijsters" title="Kim Clijsters">Kim Clijsters</a>, the 2005 Australian Open semifinal versus <a href="/wiki/Maria_Sharapova" title="Maria Sharapova">Maria Sharapova</a>, and the 2009 Wimbledon semifinal versus <a href="/wiki/Elena_Dementieva" title="Elena Dementieva">Elena Dementieva</a>), a feat achieved more often than any other player in history.<sup id="cite_ref-38" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-38">[38]</a></sup> She also came back from a 3–5 deficit in the third set against <a href="/wiki/Kim_Clijsters" title="Kim Clijsters">Kim Clijsters</a> in the 1999 US Open en route to her first Grand Slam singles title.<sup id="cite_ref-39" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-39">[39]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/2012_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2012 US Open – Women's Singles">2012 US Open</a> final against <a href="/wiki/Victoria_Azarenka" title="Victoria Azarenka">Victoria Azarenka</a>, she was down 3–5 in the third set and found herself two points away from losing the match. Williams then proceeded to win the next 4 games and defeated Azarenka.<sup id="cite_ref-40" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-40">[40]</a></sup> In the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/2015_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2015 French Open – Women's Singles">2015 French Open</a>, Williams was ill and barely able to walk during changeovers, yet beat her opponent, <a href="/wiki/Timea_Bacsinszky" title="Timea Bacsinszky">Timea Bacsinszky</a>, 6–0 in the third set.<sup id="cite_ref-41" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-41">[41]</a></sup> Another improbable win occurred in the third round of the <a href="/wiki/2015_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2015 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles">2015 Wimbledon Championships</a>, when she recovered from two breaks of service in the third set to defeat Great Britain's number-one female player, <a href="/wiki/Heather_Watson" title="Heather Watson">Heather Watson</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-42">[42]</a></sup> Williams has bounced back from a set down to win in 37 Grand Slam matches.<sup id="cite_ref-43" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-43">[43]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In recent years,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (July 2019)">when?</span></a></i>]</sup> Williams has shown an ability to serve aces at critical moments. One of these instances was the <a href="/wiki/2013_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2013 French Open – Women's Singles">2013 French Open</a> final, were in the last game of the match, she fired three aces, including one which clocked at 123<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>mph (198<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>km/h) on match point.<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-44">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-45">[45]</a></sup> She repeated the feat similarly against <a href="/wiki/Angelique_Kerber" title="Angelique Kerber">Angelique Kerber</a> in the finals of the <a href="/wiki/2016_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2016 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles">2016 Wimbledon Championships</a><sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> to tie the Open Era record for Grand Slam singles titles.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Williams fired three un-returnable serves in her final service game<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> before winning the match and the title with a casual forehand volley on the next point.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Professional_career">Professional career</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=3" title="Edit section: Professional career">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <h3><span id="1995.E2.80.931998:_Professional_debut"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1995–1998:_Professional_debut">1995–1998: Professional debut</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=4" title="Edit section: 1995–1998: Professional debut">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Williams's parents wanted their daughter to wait until she was 16 to participate in professional tournaments.<sup id="cite_ref-familytradition_46-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-familytradition-46">[46]</a></sup> In 1995 just after turning 14, Williams planned to make her professional debut as a <a href="/wiki/Wild_card_(sports)#Professional_tennis" title="Wild card (sports)">wild-card</a> entry in the <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_the_West_Classic" class="mw-redirect" title="Bank of the West Classic">Bank of the West Classic</a> in <a href="/wiki/Oakland,_California" title="Oakland, California">Oakland, California</a>, but was denied by the WTA due to age-eligibility restrictions of the organization.<sup id="cite_ref-Finn_47-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Finn-47">[47]</a></sup> She subsequently filed an antitrust lawsuit against the women's tour, but withdrew it at the behest of her parents.<sup id="cite_ref-Finn_47-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Finn-47">[47]</a></sup> Her first professional event was in October 1995 at the <a href="/wiki/Bell_Challenge" class="mw-redirect" title="Bell Challenge">Bell Challenge</a> in <a href="/wiki/Quebec" title="Quebec">Quebec</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-familytradition_46-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-familytradition-46">[46]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-48">[48]</a></sup> where she used a wild-card entry to circumvent age-eligibility rules.<sup id="cite_ref-familytradition_46-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-familytradition-46">[46]</a></sup> She lost in the first round of qualifying to then 18-year-old American <a href="/wiki/Annie_Miller_(tennis)" title="Annie Miller (tennis)">Annie Miller</a>, winning just two games.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009b114–115_49-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009b114–115-49">[49]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams did not play a tournament in 1996.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> The following year, she lost in the qualifying rounds of three tournaments,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> before winning her first main-draw match in November at the <a href="/wiki/Ameritech_Cup_Chicago" class="mw-redirect" title="Ameritech Cup Chicago">Ameritech Cup Chicago</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-youngerwilliams_50-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-youngerwilliams-50">[50]</a></sup> Ranked No. 304, she upset No. 7 <a href="/wiki/Mary_Pierce" title="Mary Pierce">Mary Pierce</a>, and No. 4 <a href="/wiki/Monica_Seles" title="Monica Seles">Monica Seles</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-51">[51]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-tennisnyt_52-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tennisnyt-52">[52]</a></sup> recording her first career wins over top<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>10 players and becoming the lowest-ranked player in the Open Era to defeat two top-10 opponents in one tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_profile_1-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_profile-1">[1]</a></sup> She ultimately lost in the semifinals to No. 5 <a href="/wiki/Lindsay_Davenport" title="Lindsay Davenport">Lindsay Davenport</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-53" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-53">[53]</a></sup> She finished 1997 ranked No. 99.<sup id="cite_ref-54" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-54">[54]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams began 1998 at the <a href="/wiki/Medibank_International_Sydney" class="mw-redirect" title="Medibank International Sydney">Medibank International Sydney</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-headtohead_55-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-headtohead-55">[55]</a></sup> As a qualifier ranked No. 96,<sup id="cite_ref-stunsdavenport_56-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stunsdavenport-56">[56]</a></sup> she defeated No. 3 Davenport in the quarterfinals,<sup id="cite_ref-stunsdavenport_56-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-stunsdavenport-56">[56]</a></sup> before losing to <a href="/wiki/Arantxa_S%C3%A1nchez_Vicario" title="Arantxa Sánchez Vicario">Arantxa Sánchez Vicario</a> in the semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-57" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-57">[57]</a></sup> Williams made her debut in the main draw of a Grand Slam tournament at the <a href="/wiki/1998_Australian_Open" title="1998 Australian Open">Australian Open</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-58" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-58">[58]</a></sup> where she defeated sixth-seeded <a href="/wiki/Irina_Sp%C3%AErlea" title="Irina Spîrlea">Irina Spîrlea</a> in the first round,<sup id="cite_ref-Irina_59-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Irina-59">[59]</a></sup> before losing to her sister, Venus, in the second round in the first professional match for the sisters.<sup id="cite_ref-Irina_59-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Irina-59">[59]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-headtohead_55-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-headtohead-55">[55]</a></sup> Williams reached six other quarterfinals during the year, but lost all of them,<sup id="cite_ref-Looney_60-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Looney-60">[60]</a></sup> including her first match against No. 1-ranked <a href="/wiki/Martina_Hingis" title="Martina Hingis">Martina Hingis</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Lipton_International_Players_Championships" class="mw-redirect" title="Lipton International Players Championships">Lipton International Players Championships</a> in Key Biscayne,<sup id="cite_ref-61" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-61">[61]</a></sup> and her second match against Venus at the <a href="/wiki/Rome_Masters" class="mw-redirect" title="Rome Masters">Italian Open</a> in Rome.<sup id="cite_ref-Looney_60-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Looney-60">[60]</a></sup> She failed to reach the quarterfinals of any Grand Slam tournament the remainder of the year,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (April 2017)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> losing in the fourth round of the French Open to Arantxa Sánchez Vicario,<sup id="cite_ref-62" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-62">[62]</a></sup> and the third round of the <a href="/wiki/US_Open_(tennis)" title="US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> to Spîrlea.<sup id="cite_ref-63" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-63">[63]</a></sup> She withdrew from <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a> two games into a match with <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Ruano_Pascual" title="Virginia Ruano Pascual">Virginia Ruano Pascual</a>, after straining her calf muscle during the first set.<sup id="cite_ref-64" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-64">[64]</a></sup> She did win the mixed doubles titles at <a href="/wiki/1998_Wimbledon_Championships" title="1998 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a> and the <a href="/wiki/1998_US_Open_(tennis)" title="1998 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> with <a href="/wiki/Max_Mirnyi" title="Max Mirnyi">Max Mirnyi</a>, completing the Williams family's sweep of the 1998 mixed doubles Grand Slam tournaments. Williams won her first professional title in doubles in Oklahoma City with Venus, becoming the third pair of sisters to win a WTA title.<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_profile_1-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_profile-1">[1]</a></sup> Williams and her sister won two more doubles titles together during the year. Williams finished the year ranked No. 20 in singles.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Battle_of_the_sexes:_Karsten_Braasch_vs._the_Williams_sisters">Battle of the sexes: Karsten Braasch vs. the Williams sisters</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=5" title="Edit section: Battle of the sexes: Karsten Braasch vs. the Williams sisters">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h4> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Sexes_(tennis)#1998:_Karsten_Braasch_vs._the_Williams_sisters" title="Battle of the Sexes (tennis)">Battle of the Sexes (tennis)</a>
      </div> 
      <p>A 16-year-old Serena competed in a tennis "Battle of the Sexes", along with her sister <a href="/wiki/Venus_Williams" title="Venus Williams">Venus Williams</a>, against <a href="/wiki/Karsten_Braasch" title="Karsten Braasch">Karsten Braasch</a> at the 1998 Australian Open.<sup id="cite_ref-65" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-65">[65]</a></sup> At the time Braasch was 203rd in the ATP rankings. The Williams sisters had claimed they could beat any man outside the top 200, and accepted his challenge. Braasch beat both Williams sisters, playing a single set against each. The score vs Serena was 6–1 and vs Venus 6–2.<sup id="cite_ref-66" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-66">[66]</a></sup> Braasch said afterward, "500 and above, no chance." The sisters later tweaked the number to beating men outside the top 350.<sup id="cite_ref-67" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-67">[67]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="1999.E2.80.932001:_Becoming_a_top-10_player"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="1999–2001:_Becoming_a_top-10_player">1999–2001: Becoming a top-10 player</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=6" title="Edit section: 1999–2001: Becoming a top-10 player">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Williams lost in the third round of the <a href="/wiki/1999_Australian_Open" title="1999 Australian Open">1999 Australian Open</a> to <a href="/wiki/Sandrine_Testud" title="Sandrine Testud">Sandrine Testud</a>. A month later, Williams won her first professional singles title when she defeated <a href="/wiki/Am%C3%A9lie_Mauresmo" title="Amélie Mauresmo">Amélie Mauresmo</a> in the final of the <a href="/wiki/Open_Gaz_de_France" class="mw-redirect" title="Open Gaz de France">Open Gaz de France</a> in Paris. With Venus also winning the <a href="/wiki/Cellular_South_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="Cellular South Cup">IGA Superthrift Classic</a> in Memphis, Tennessee that day, the pair became the first sisters to win professional tournaments in the same week.<sup id="cite_ref-68" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-68">[68]</a></sup> In March of that year, at the <a href="/wiki/BNP_Paribas_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="BNP Paribas Open">Evert Cup</a> in California, Williams won her first <a href="/wiki/Tier_I" class="mw-redirect" title="Tier I">Tier I</a> title, defeating <a href="/wiki/Steffi_Graf" title="Steffi Graf">Steffi Graf</a> in the final. Soon afterward at the <a href="/wiki/Miami_Masters" class="mw-redirect" title="Miami Masters">Miami Masters</a>, Williams had her 16-match winning streak ended by her sister in the first all-sister singles final in WTA history,<sup id="cite_ref-headtohead_55-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-headtohead-55">[55]</a></sup> and she then made her top-10 debut, at No. 9. She then lost in the quarterfinals of the <a href="/wiki/Italian_Open_(tennis)" title="Italian Open (tennis)">Italian Open</a><sup id="cite_ref-69" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-69">[69]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/German_Open_(WTA)" title="German Open (WTA)">German Open</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-70" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-70">[70]</a></sup> and the third round of the <a href="/wiki/1999_French_Open" title="1999 French Open">French Open</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-71" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-71">[71]</a></sup> where she and Venus won the women's doubles title.<sup id="cite_ref-headtohead_55-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-headtohead-55">[55]</a></sup> Williams then missed <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a> because of injury. When she returned to the tour, Williams won a <a href="/wiki/Fed_Cup" title="Fed Cup">Fed Cup</a> singles match and then won the <a href="/wiki/JPMorgan_Chase_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="JPMorgan Chase Open">JPMorgan Chase Open</a> in Los Angeles, beating <a href="/wiki/Julie_Halard-Decugis" title="Julie Halard-Decugis">Julie Halard-Decugis</a> in the final. She then defeated in succession Grand Slam champions <a href="/wiki/Kim_Clijsters" title="Kim Clijsters">Kim Clijsters</a>, <a href="/wiki/Conchita_Mart%C3%ADnez" title="Conchita Martínez">Conchita Martínez</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monica_Seles" title="Monica Seles">Monica Seles</a>, and defending champion Lindsay Davenport to reach the <a href="/wiki/1999_US_Open_(tennis)" title="1999 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> final, where she defeated No. 1, Hingis, to become the second African-American woman, after <a href="/wiki/Althea_Gibson" title="Althea Gibson">Althea Gibson</a> in 1958, to win a Grand Slam singles tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_profile_1-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_profile-1">[1]</a></sup> The Williams sisters also won the doubles title at this tournament. To complete her 1999 season, Williams won a doubles match in the Fed Cup final against Russia. Williams ended the year ranked No. 4 in just her second full year on the main tour.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams started 2000 by losing in the fourth round of the <a href="/wiki/2000_Australian_Open" title="2000 Australian Open">Australian Open</a> to <a href="/wiki/Elena_Likhovtseva" title="Elena Likhovtseva">Elena Likhovtseva</a>. She failed to defend her titles in Paris and Indian Wells, although she did win the <a href="/wiki/Faber_Grand_Prix" title="Faber Grand Prix">Faber Grand Prix</a> in Germany. Soon afterwards, Williams missed the <a href="/wiki/2000_French_Open" title="2000 French Open">French Open</a> because of injury. She returned from injury at the <a href="/wiki/2000_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2000 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon Championships</a>, where she lost to Venus in the semifinals, but the pair won the doubles title at the event. Williams successfully defended her title in Los Angeles, defeating Davenport in the final. She reached the final of the <a href="/wiki/Rogers_Cup_(tennis)" class="mw-redirect" title="Rogers Cup (tennis)">Du Maurier Open</a> where an injury forced her to retire from her match with Hingis. Her defense of the <a href="/wiki/2000_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2000 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> title ended when she lost in the quarterfinals to Davenport. Williams teamed with Venus to win the gold medal in doubles at the <a href="/wiki/Sydney_Olympics" class="mw-redirect" title="Sydney Olympics">Sydney Olympics</a> that September. She ended the year winning the <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Princess_Cup" title="Toyota Princess Cup">Toyota Princess Cup</a> in Japan and she finished the year ranked No. 6.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams began 2001 losing to Martina Hingis in the quarterfinals of the Medibank International in <a href="/wiki/Medibank_International" class="mw-redirect" title="Medibank International">Sydney</a> and the Australian Open in Melbourne. Williams and her sister won the doubles title at the latter tournament, becoming only the fifth doubles team in history to win all four Grand Slam women's doubles titles during their career, completing a "Career Grand Slam". Her next event was the <a href="/wiki/Pacific_Life_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="Pacific Life Open">Pacific Life Open</a> in California, where she defeated Kim Clijsters in the final. The final was marred by the behavior of the crowd toward Williams and her family. Crowd members were incensed at the perceived match-fixing of games involving the family after <a href="/wiki/Boycott_of_BNP_Paribas_Open_by_Venus_and_Serena_Williams" class="mw-redirect" title="Boycott of BNP Paribas Open by Venus and Serena Williams">Venus withdrew</a> before their semifinal. Neither Williams nor her sister entered the tournament for fourteen years until Williams entered in 2015 as a wildcard (and the top seed).<sup id="cite_ref-72" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-72">[72]</a></sup> The following week at the <a href="/wiki/Ericsson_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="Ericsson Open">Ericsson Open</a> in Miami, Williams lost to <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Capriati" title="Jennifer Capriati">Jennifer Capriati</a> in the quarterfinals. She then lost in the quarterfinals to Capriati at both the <a href="/wiki/2001_French_Open" title="2001 French Open">French Open</a> and <a href="/wiki/2001_Wimbledon" class="mw-redirect" title="2001 Wimbledon">Wimbledon Championships</a>. That was the fourth consecutive Grand Slam tournament at which Williams had exited in the quarterfinals. During the North American hard-court season, she lost in the quarterfinals of <a href="/wiki/East_West_Bank_Classic" class="mw-redirect" title="East West Bank Classic">Los Angeles</a> against Monica Seles, then captured her second title of the year at the <a href="/wiki/Rogers_Cup_(tennis)" class="mw-redirect" title="Rogers Cup (tennis)">Rogers Cup</a>, defeating Capriati in the final. Williams reached the final of the 2001 US Open, losing to sister Venus. That was the first Grand Slam tournament final contested by two sisters during the Open Era. At the 2001 season-ending <a href="/wiki/WTA_Tour_Championships" class="mw-redirect" title="WTA Tour Championships">Tour Championships</a>, Williams won the championship by walkover when Davenport withdrew before the start of the final due to a knee injury. Williams finished 2001 at No. 6 for the second straight year.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2002.E2.80.932003:_.22Serena_Slam.22"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2002–2003:_&quot;Serena_Slam&quot;">2002–2003: "Serena Slam"</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=7" title="Edit section: 2002–2003: &quot;Serena Slam&quot;">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3>
      <p> Early 2002, injury saw Williams retire from the semifinal at the <a href="/wiki/Medibank_International_Sydney" class="mw-redirect" title="Medibank International Sydney">Medibank International Sydney</a> and later withdraw from the <a href="/wiki/2002_Australian_Open" title="2002 Australian Open">Australian Open</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-73" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-73">[73]</a></sup> </p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:SWilliams-SYD-1.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/SWilliams-SYD-1.jpg/220px-SWilliams-SYD-1.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="197" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/SWilliams-SYD-1.jpg/330px-SWilliams-SYD-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a8/SWilliams-SYD-1.jpg/440px-SWilliams-SYD-1.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1024" data-file-height="918"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:SWilliams-SYD-1.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>
         <div style="text-align: center;">
          Playing Amélie Mauresmo in the quarterfinals of the tournament in Sydney in 2002
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Returning from injury, Williams won her first title of the year in <a href="/wiki/State_Farm_Women%27s_Tennis_Classic" title="State Farm Women's Tennis Classic">Scottsdale, Arizona</a>, defeating No. 2 Jennifer Capriati, in the final. She then won the Miami Masters for the first time, becoming one of three players in the Open Era to defeat the world's top 3 ranked players at one tournament,<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_profile_1-7" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_profile-1">[1]</a></sup> after beating No. 3, Martina Hingis, in the quarterfinals, No. 2 Venus in the semifinals, and the top-ranked player, Capriati, in the final. Serena's straight set win over Venus was her second career win over her sister.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams played three clay-court tournaments before the <a href="/wiki/2002_French_Open" title="2002 French Open">2002 French Open</a>. Her first tournament was at <a href="/wiki/Family_Circle_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="Family Circle Cup">Charleston</a>, where she was the third seed. Williams reached the quarterfinals before losing to <a href="/wiki/Patty_Schnyder" title="Patty Schnyder">Patty Schnyder</a>. She reached her first clay-court final in May, at the <a href="/wiki/WTA_German_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="WTA German Open">Eurocard German Open</a> losing to <a href="/wiki/Justine_Henin" title="Justine Henin">Justine Henin</a> in a third set tiebreak. Williams went on to win her first clay court title at the <a href="/wiki/Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia" class="mw-redirect" title="Internazionali BNL d'Italia">Italian Open</a>, defeating Capriati in the semifinals and Henin in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-74" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-74">[74]</a></sup> This raised her ranking to a new high of No. 3. Williams was the third seed at the French Open at Roland Garros, where she claimed her first title there by defeating defending champion Capriati in the semifinals and sister Venus in the final to win her second Grand Slam tournament title (and her first in two-and-a-half years). As a result of raising the trophy at <a href="/wiki/Court_Philippe_Chatrier" class="mw-redirect" title="Court Philippe Chatrier">Court Philippe Chatrier</a>, Williams rose to a career high of No. 2, second only to Venus.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2002_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2002 Wimbledon Championships">2002 Wimbledon Championships</a>, Williams won tennis' oldest championship for the first time in her life, defeating Venus to win a Grand Slam singles title without dropping a set for the first time in her career. This victory earned Williams the world No. 1 ranking for the first time, dethroning her sister and becoming only the third African American woman to hold that ranking.<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_profile_1-8" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_profile-1">[1]</a></sup> The Williams sisters also won the doubles title at the tournament, the fifth Grand Slam doubles title for the pair. Williams played just one tournament between Wimbledon and the <a href="/wiki/2002_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2002 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, losing in the quarterfinals of the <a href="/wiki/JPMorgan_Chase_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="JPMorgan Chase Open">JPMorgan Chase Open</a> in Los Angeles to American <a href="/wiki/Chanda_Rubin" title="Chanda Rubin">Chanda Rubin</a> and ending a 21-match winning streak. The top-seeded player at the US Open, Williams reached the final where, for the third Grand Slam in a row, she defeated her sister to win the title, the second US Open crown of her career. Williams won two consecutive singles titles in the fall, defeating Kim Clijsters to win the <a href="/wiki/Toyota_Princess_Cup" title="Toyota Princess Cup">Toyota Princess Cup</a> in Tokyo, and <a href="/wiki/Anastasia_Myskina" title="Anastasia Myskina">Anastasia Myskina</a> to win the <a href="/wiki/Sparkassen_Cup_(tennis)" title="Sparkassen Cup (tennis)">Sparkassen Cup</a> in Leipzig, Germany. She reached the final at the year-end <a href="/wiki/WTA_Tour_Championships" class="mw-redirect" title="WTA Tour Championships">Home Depot Championships</a> at the <a href="/wiki/Staples_Center" title="Staples Center">Staples Center</a> in Los Angeles, where she lost to fifth-seeded Clijsters in straight sets, ending an 18-match winning streak.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams finished 2002 with a 56–5 W/L record, eight singles titles, and the No. 1 ranking. She was the first African-American to end a year with that ranking since <a href="/wiki/Althea_Gibson" title="Althea Gibson">Althea Gibson</a> in 1958<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> and was the first woman to win three Grand Slam tournament titles in one year since Hingis in 1997.<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_profile_1-9" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_profile-1">[1]</a></sup> Her three consecutive Grand Slam titles to close 2002 also made Williams only the third player in tennis history to win the "Surface Slam",<sup id="cite_ref-75" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-75">[75]</a></sup> three Slam titles on three surfaces in the same calendar year, after Navratilova (1984) and Graf (1993, 1995, 1996).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2003_Australian_Open" title="2003 Australian Open">2003 Australian Open</a>, Williams reached the tournament's semifinals for the first time, where she recovered from 5–1 down in the third set and saved two match points before defeating Clijsters. In the final, Serena faced Venus for the fourth consecutive Grand Slam tournament final, defeating her older sister to become the sixth woman in the Open Era to complete a career Grand Slam, alongside <a href="/wiki/Margaret_Court" title="Margaret Court">Margaret Court</a>, <a href="/wiki/Billie_Jean_King" title="Billie Jean King">Billie Jean King</a>, <a href="/wiki/Chris_Evert" title="Chris Evert">Chris Evert</a>, <a href="/wiki/Martina_Navratilova" title="Martina Navratilova">Martina Navratilova</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Steffi_Graf" title="Steffi Graf">Steffi Graf</a>. She also became the fifth woman to hold all Grand Slam singles titles simultaneously, joining <a href="/wiki/Maureen_Connolly_Brinker" class="mw-redirect" title="Maureen Connolly Brinker">Maureen Connolly Brinker</a>, Court, Graf, and Navratilova. This feat was dubbed the <b>"Serena Slam"</b> by the press.<sup id="cite_ref-76" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-76">[76]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-77" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-77">[77]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Williams_sisters" title="Williams sisters">Williams sisters</a> won their sixth Grand Slam doubles title together at this event.<sup id="cite_ref-78" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-78">[78]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>During the spring of 2003, Williams captured the singles titles at the <a href="/wiki/Open_Gaz_de_France" class="mw-redirect" title="Open Gaz de France">Open Gaz de France</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sony_Ericsson_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="Sony Ericsson Open">Sony Ericsson Open</a>. Williams's winning streak came to an end when she lost the final of the <a href="/wiki/Family_Circle_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="Family Circle Cup">Family Circle Cup</a> to Henin, her first loss of the year after 21 wins. She also lost to Mauresmo in the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia" class="mw-redirect" title="Internazionali BNL d'Italia">Internazionali BNL d'Italia</a> in Rome. Despite these losses, Williams was the top seed at the <a href="/wiki/2003_French_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2003 French Open – Women's Singles">French Open</a>, where she lost in the semifinals to eventual champion Henin, marking Williams's first loss in a Grand Slam tournament since 2001. The match was controversial, as Williams questioned Henin's sportsmanship, and spectators applauded Williams's errors.<sup id="cite_ref-79" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-79">[79]</a></sup> Williams rebounded from the French Open loss a couple weeks later at the <a href="/wiki/2003_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2003 Wimbledon Championships">2003 Wimbledon Championships</a>, defeating Henin in the semifinals and Venus in the final. This was Williams's second consecutive Wimbledon title and her sixth Grand Slam singles title overall. Wimbledon was Williams's last tournament of 2003; she pulled out of three events in the US and then underwent surgery on the quadriceps tendon in her knee in early August. Williams was initially expected to be out for six to eight weeks.<sup id="cite_ref-80" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-80">[80]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2004.E2.80.932007:_Injuries_and_the_comeback"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2004–2007:_Injuries_and_the_comeback">2004–2007: Injuries and the comeback</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=8" title="Edit section: 2004–2007: Injuries and the comeback">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: 
       <a href="/wiki/2004_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2004 Serena Williams tennis season">2004</a>, 
       <a href="/wiki/2005_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2005 Serena Williams tennis season">2005</a>, 
       <a href="/wiki/2006_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2006 Serena Williams tennis season">2006</a>, and 
       <a href="/wiki/2007_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2007 Serena Williams tennis season">2007 Serena Williams tennis season</a>
      </div>
      <p> After eight months away from the tour, during which time her desire was questioned,<sup id="cite_ref-81" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-81">[81]</a></sup> Williams began her comeback at the 2004 <a href="/wiki/NASDAQ-100_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="NASDAQ-100 Open">NASDAQ-100 Open</a> in Miami in March, where she made a triumphant return as she won the title for the third consecutive year.</p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Serena_serving.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Serena_serving.jpg/220px-Serena_serving.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="293" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Serena_serving.jpg/330px-Serena_serving.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f2/Serena_serving.jpg/440px-Serena_serving.jpg 2x" data-file-width="450" data-file-height="600"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Serena_serving.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>
         <div style="text-align: center;">
          Delivering a serve at an exhibition in November 2004
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Although ranked No. 7, Williams was seeded second at the French Open, where, after winning four matches, she lost to Capriati in the quarterfinals. That was the first time that Williams had lost before the semifinals at a Grand Slam singles tournament since Wimbledon in 2001. A few weeks later, even though her ranking had dropped to No. 10, Williams was seeded first at <a href="/wiki/2004_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2004 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a>. She won six matches en route to the final, where 13th-seeded Sharapova defeated her in straight sets. This loss caused her ranking to drop out of the top 10 for the first time since 1999. Later that summer, Williams reached her third final of the year at the JPMorgan Chase Open in Los Angeles where she lost to Lindsay Davenport which was her first loss to the American since the 2000 US Open. After missing her national championship in 2003, Williams returned for the 2004 <a href="/wiki/2004_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2004 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, where she was seeded third despite her No. 11 ranking. She lost in the U.S. Open quarterfinals to Capriati in three sets in controversial fashion.<sup id="cite_ref-82" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-82">[82]</a></sup> That fall, Williams won her second title of the year, at the <a href="/wiki/China_Open_(tennis)" title="China Open (tennis)">China Open</a>, defeating US Open champion <a href="/wiki/Svetlana_Kuznetsova" title="Svetlana Kuznetsova">Svetlana Kuznetsova</a> in the final. Williams' successful season allowed her to qualify for the <a href="/wiki/2004_WTA_Tour_Championships" title="2004 WTA Tour Championships">Tour Championships</a>, held again in Los Angeles. In the round-robin phase of the tournament, Williams defeated Dementieva and <a href="/wiki/Anastasia_Myskina" title="Anastasia Myskina">Anastasia Myskina</a> and lost to Davenport, but still advanced to the elimination stage. After winning her semifinal, she lost to Sharapova in the final, where she suffered an abdominal injury.<sup id="cite_ref-83" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-83">[83]</a></sup> Williams finished 2004 ranked No. 7, but did not win a Grand Slam singles tournament for the first season since 2001.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2005_Australian_Open" title="2005 Australian Open">2005 Australian Open</a>, Williams rejected suggestions that she and sister Venus were a declining force in tennis, following Venus's early exit.<sup id="cite_ref-84" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-84">[84]</a></sup> Williams saved three match points to defeat Sharapova 8–6 in the third of their semifinal. In the final, Williams defeated top seed Davenport to win her second Australian Open and seventh Grand Slam singles title, winning 12 of the last 15 games.<sup id="cite_ref-85" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-85">[85]</a></sup> The win moved Williams back to No. 2 but stated she was targeting the top spot.<sup id="cite_ref-86" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-86">[86]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams completed just two tournaments between the Australian Open and Wimbledon, losing to Venus in Miami and at Internazionali BNL d'Italia to <a href="/wiki/Francesca_Schiavone" title="Francesca Schiavone">Francesca Schiavone</a> as Williams suffered a series of retirements and withdraws.<sup id="cite_ref-87" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-87">[87]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-88" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-88">[88]</a></sup> A reoccurring ankle injury causing her to miss the <a href="/wiki/2005_French_Open" title="2005 French Open">French Open</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-89" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-89">[89]</a></sup> She returned for <a href="/wiki/2005_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2005 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a> as the 4th-seeded player, but was defeated in the third round by No. 85, <a href="/wiki/Jill_Craybas" title="Jill Craybas">Jill Craybas</a>. At the <a href="/wiki/2005_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2005 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, Williams lost to her sister Venus in the fourth round. This was the earliest the sisters had met in a Grand Slam tournament since their first meeting, at the 1998 Australian Open. Williams played just one more match that fall, a loss to No. 127 <a href="/wiki/Sun_Tiantian" title="Sun Tiantian">Sun Tiantian</a> at the <a href="/wiki/China_Open_(tennis)" title="China Open (tennis)">tournament in Beijing</a>. She failed to qualify for the year-end championship for the first time since 1998 and she finished the year 2005 ranked No. 11, her first time finishing the season outside the top 10 since 1998.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams made her 2006 debut at the <a href="/wiki/2006_Australian_Open" title="2006 Australian Open">Australian Open</a>. Defending the title, Williams lost to <a href="/wiki/Daniela_Hantuchov%C3%A1" title="Daniela Hantuchová">Daniela Hantuchová</a> in the third round.<sup id="cite_ref-90" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-90">[90]</a></sup> After the tournament, she told the press that she was injured, blaming a lack of fitness and a knee injury for keeping her off the court.<sup id="cite_ref-91" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-91">[91]</a></sup> In her biography, Williams claims that she was actually suffering from depression. She stayed away from pro tennis for six months during the 2006 season. After she had shut herself off from the world for a period, Williams saw a therapist daily.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009a175–176_92-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009a175–176-92">[92]</a></sup> After a chance meeting with a young girl who idolized Williams and believed that she could still win, Williams signed up to play in Cincinnati,<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009a198–199_93-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009a198–199-93">[93]</a></sup> her first tournament since Melbourne. Williams had slipped to No. 139, the lowest ranking she had held since 1997. On her return, Williams defeated Myskina and <a href="/wiki/Bethanie_Mattek" class="mw-redirect" title="Bethanie Mattek">Bethanie Mattek</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-94" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-94">[94]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-95" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-95">[95]</a></sup> before losing in the semifinals to <a href="/wiki/Vera_Zvonareva" title="Vera Zvonareva">Vera Zvonareva</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-96" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-96">[96]</a></sup> She also reached the semifinals in Los Angeles, losing to Janković in straight sets. At the <a href="/wiki/2006_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2006 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, Williams needed a wildcard to enter the tournament, as her ranking at the cut-off time was No. 139, outside the automatic 102. Her ranking had improved to 79th by the time the tournament came around.<sup id="cite_ref-97" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-97">[97]</a></sup> She lost to top-seeded Mauresmo in the fourth round.<sup id="cite_ref-98" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-98">[98]</a></sup> Following the US Open, she did not play again in 2006, ending the year ranked No. 95, her lowest year-end ranking since 1997.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams began 2007 with renewed confidence, stating her intention to return to the top of the rankings,<sup id="cite_ref-targets#1_99-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-targets#1-99">[99]</a></sup> a comment 1987 Wimbledon men's singles champion and commentator <a href="/wiki/Pat_Cash" title="Pat Cash">Pat Cash</a> branded "deluded".<sup id="cite_ref-cash_100-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-cash-100">[100]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams lost in the quarterfinals of the <a href="/wiki/Moorilla_Hobart_International" class="mw-redirect" title="Moorilla Hobart International">Hobart International</a>, a warm-up for the <a href="/wiki/2007_Australian_Open" title="2007 Australian Open">Australian Open</a> where Williams was unseeded because of her No. 81 ranking and was widely regarded as "out of shape".<sup id="cite_ref-shape_101-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shape-101">[101]</a></sup> She experienced a huge amount of pressure on herself before the tournament, coming from her fans and the press as well as Williams herself about her weight, focus and needing a good showing.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Shortly before her first match, a representative from Nike paid her a visit in the players' lounge, informing her that if she did not perform to her accustomed level, the company might drop her. Williams claimed that Nike's ultimatum meant that she would have to reach the quarterfinals at least.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009a205–206_102-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009a205–206-102">[102]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The distraction from Nike did not distract Williams, as she lost just three games to <a href="/wiki/Mara_Santangelo" title="Mara Santangelo">Mara Santangelo</a> and defeated Anne Kremer in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009a206_103-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009a206-103">[103]</a></sup> By this point, a blister had developed on Williams's foot and she had contracted a cold. In the third round, Williams found herself two points away from going home against <a href="/wiki/Nadia_Petrova" title="Nadia Petrova">Nadia Petrova</a>, but fought back to win in three sets, which was her first win over a top-10 player since defeating Lindsay Davenport in the 2005 Australian Open final. Williams then made it to the final, defeating Janković, Pe'er and Vaidišová. Williams described them as "good players. Strong players. Players who certainly didn't expect an overweight, out-of-shape, has been champion like me to give them a game."<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009b208–209_104-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009b208–209-104">[104]</a></sup> Williams also found herself two points from going out against Peer before turning it around.<sup id="cite_ref-NY_2007_AUS_105-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY_2007_AUS-105">[105]</a></sup> By the time Williams had reached the final, the cold and blister had both left. Previewing the finals, <a href="/wiki/Tracy_Austin" title="Tracy Austin">Tracy Austin</a> stated that, although Williams had a great tournament, she believed that the ride was over and that Sharapova would have no trouble with Williams. Williams thought it was mean and unnecessary and used it as motivation along with other criticism.<sup id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009b209_106-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWilliamsPaisner2009b209-106">[106]</a></sup> In the final, Williams lost just three games against Maria Sharapova, winning her first title at any tournament since winning the 2005 Australian Open 24 months prior.<sup id="cite_ref-NY_2007_AUS_105-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NY_2007_AUS-105">[105]</a></sup> Williams became the first player since <a href="/wiki/Chris_O%27Neil_(tennis)" title="Chris O'Neil (tennis)">Chris O'Neil</a> to win the title while not being seeded, and claimed her third Australian Open and eighth Grand Slam singles title overall. The win elevated Williams to 14th in the rankings. Williams dedicated the title to her deceased half-sister Yetunde.<sup id="cite_ref-ausopen07_107-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ausopen07-107">[107]</a></sup> Her performance in the final was described in the press as "one of the best performances of her career" and "arguably the most powerful display ever seen in women's tennis".<sup id="cite_ref-shape_101-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-shape-101">[101]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-108" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-108">[108]</a></sup> In her post match interview, Williams took a swipe at her critics, stating that she had proved them wrong.<sup id="cite_ref-109" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-109">[109]</a></sup> Williams won the <a href="/wiki/Sony_Ericsson_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="Sony Ericsson Open">Sony Ericsson Open</a> in Miami for the fourth time by defeating Justine Henin. Williams had to record a come-from-behind win after being whitewashed in the first set and saving two match points in the second.<sup id="cite_ref-110" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-110">[110]</a></sup> She played for her country in the Fed Cup for the first time since 2003 in a tie against <a href="/wiki/Belgium_Fed_Cup_team" title="Belgium Fed Cup team">Belgium</a>, and won her opening match<sup id="cite_ref-111" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-111">[111]</a></sup> but withdrew from her second, because of a knee injury.<sup id="cite_ref-112" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-112">[112]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2007_French_Open" title="2007 French Open">French Open</a>, Williams lost in the quarterfinals to Henin.<sup id="cite_ref-activity_113-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-activity-113">[113]</a></sup> During her fourth round match against Hantuchová at Wimbledon, Williams collapsed from an acute muscle spasm at 5–5 in the second set. After a medical timeout and holding serve to force a tiebreak, rain forced play to be suspended for nearly two hours. When the players returned, Williams won the match in three sets.<sup id="cite_ref-114" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-114">[114]</a></sup> Williams then lost her quarterfinal match with Henin, whilst suffering from the injuries sustained in the previous round.<sup id="cite_ref-115" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-115">[115]</a></sup> At the US Open, Williams lost her third consecutive Grand Slam singles quarterfinal to Henin.<sup id="cite_ref-116" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-116">[116]</a></sup> Williams reached the final of <a href="/wiki/Kremlin_Cup" title="Kremlin Cup">Kremlin Cup</a>, losing to <a href="/wiki/Elena_Dementieva" title="Elena Dementieva">Elena Dementieva</a>. Williams qualified for the WTA Championships, but retired from her first match with <a href="/wiki/Anna_Chakvetadze" title="Anna Chakvetadze">Anna Chakvetadze</a> with a knee injury and subsequently withdrew from the event.<sup id="cite_ref-117" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-117">[117]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-118" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-118">[118]</a></sup> Williams finished 2007 as No. 7 and the top-ranked American for the first time since 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-activity_113-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-activity-113">[113]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2008.E2.80.932010:_Back_to_No._1_and_injuries"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2008–2010:_Back_to_No._1_and_injuries">2008–2010: Back to No. 1 and injuries</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=9" title="Edit section: 2008–2010: Back to No. 1 and injuries">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: 
       <a href="/wiki/2008_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2008 Serena Williams tennis season">2008</a>, 
       <a href="/wiki/2009_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2009 Serena Williams tennis season">2009</a>, and 
       <a href="/wiki/2010_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2010 Serena Williams tennis season">2010 Serena Williams tennis season</a>
      </div>
      <p> Williams started 2008 by participating on the U.S. team that won the <a href="/wiki/Hopman_Cup" title="Hopman Cup">Hopman Cup</a> with <a href="/wiki/Mardy_Fish" title="Mardy Fish">Mardy Fish</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-119" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-119">[119]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2008_Australian_Open" title="2008 Australian Open">Australian Open</a> she lost in the quarterfinals to <a href="/wiki/Jelena_Jankovi%C4%87" title="Jelena Janković">Jelena Janković</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-activity_113-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-activity-113">[113]</a></sup> her fourth straight loss in the quarterfinals of a Grand Slam singles tournament. In the women's doubles event, she and Venus were defeated in the quarterfinals. Williams withdrew from her next three scheduled tournaments because of an urgent need for dental surgery.<sup id="cite_ref-120" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-120">[120]</a></sup> Williams then won three consecutive singles titles at <a href="/wiki/Bangalore_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="Bangalore Open">Bangalore</a> and her fifth <a href="/wiki/Sony_Ericsson_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="Sony Ericsson Open">Miami</a> title, tying Steffi Graf for the most singles titles at this tournament.</p>
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Serena_Williams_Australian_Open_2009_5.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Serena_Williams_Australian_Open_2009_5.jpg/220px-Serena_Williams_Australian_Open_2009_5.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="309" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Serena_Williams_Australian_Open_2009_5.jpg/330px-Serena_Williams_Australian_Open_2009_5.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/26/Serena_Williams_Australian_Open_2009_5.jpg/440px-Serena_Williams_Australian_Open_2009_5.jpg 2x" data-file-width="779" data-file-height="1093"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Serena_Williams_Australian_Open_2009_5.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>
         <div style="text-align: center;">
          At the 2009 Australian Open
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams won at the <a href="/wiki/Family_Circle_Cup" class="mw-redirect" title="Family Circle Cup">Family Circle Cup</a>, her first clay-court title since the 2002 French Open. Her 17-match winning streak was ended by <a href="/wiki/Dinara_Safina" title="Dinara Safina">Dinara Safina</a> in the quarterfinals of <a href="/wiki/Qatar_Telecom_German_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="Qatar Telecom German Open">Berlin</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-activity_113-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-activity-113">[113]</a></sup> Williams withdrew in <a href="/wiki/2008_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia" class="mw-redirect" title="2008 Internazionali BNL d'Italia">Rome</a> in the quarterfinals against <a href="/wiki/Aliz%C3%A9_Cornet" title="Alizé Cornet">Alizé Cornet</a> due to a back injury. Williams was the only former winner of the <a href="/wiki/2008_French_Open" title="2008 French Open">French Open</a> in the draw, but lost in the third round to <a href="/wiki/Katarina_Srebotnik" title="Katarina Srebotnik">Katarina Srebotnik</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a>, Williams reached the finals for the first time in four years but lost to her older sister Venus in straight sets, in their first Slam final since 2003. Serena and Venus teamed to win the women's doubles title in their first Grand Slam women's doubles title since 2003. Williams played at <a href="/wiki/Bank_of_the_West_Classic" class="mw-redirect" title="Bank of the West Classic">Stanford</a>, but retired 6–2, 3–1 down with a left knee injury from her semifinal match against qualifier <a href="/wiki/Aleksandra_Wozniak" title="Aleksandra Wozniak">Aleksandra Wozniak</a>. The injury forced her to withdraw from <a href="/wiki/East_West_Bank_Classic" class="mw-redirect" title="East West Bank Classic">Los Angeles</a>. At the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2008_Summer_Olympics" title="Tennis at the 2008 Summer Olympics">Olympics</a> in Beijing, Williams lost to Dementieva in the quarterfinals. Serena and Venus won the gold medal in doubles, beating <a href="/wiki/Anabel_Medina_Garrigues" title="Anabel Medina Garrigues">Anabel Medina Garrigues</a> and <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Ruano_Pascual" title="Virginia Ruano Pascual">Virginia Ruano Pascual</a> in the final. At the <a href="/wiki/2008_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2008 US Open – Women's Singles">US Open</a>, Williams defeated sister Venus, Safina and Jelena Janković in the final. That was her third US Open and ninth Grand Slam singles title. The victory returned her to the No. 1 ranking for the first time since 2003.<sup id="cite_ref-121" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-121">[121]</a></sup> At the year-end championships she defeated Safina and lost to Venus in her round-robin matches, but withdrew from her match against Dementieva, citing a stomach muscle injury. She ended 2008 ranked No. 2 and with four singles titles, her strongest performance in both respects since 2003.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams began 2009 at the <a href="/wiki/2009_Sydney_International" class="mw-redirect" title="2009 Sydney International">Medibank International</a> losing in the semifinals to <a href="/wiki/Elena_Dementieva" title="Elena Dementieva">Elena Dementieva</a>. At the <a href="/wiki/2009_Australian_Open" title="2009 Australian Open">Australian Open</a>, she claimed her tenth Grand Slam singles title by defeating <a href="/wiki/Dinara_Safina" title="Dinara Safina">Dinara Safina</a> in the final in 59 minutes. This win returned her to the No. 1 ranking and resulted in her becoming the all-time career prize money leader in women's sports, overtaking golfer <a href="/wiki/Annika_S%C3%B6renstam" title="Annika Sörenstam">Annika Sörenstam</a>. In women's doubles, with Venus, they captured the title for the third time.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2009_Open_GDF_Suez_%E2%80%93_Singles" title="2009 Open GDF Suez – Singles">Open GdF Suez</a>, Williams withdrew before her semifinal with Dementieva because of a knee injury.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources.
