(July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Serena then played at <a href="/wiki/2009_Dubai_Tennis_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2009 Dubai Tennis Championships – Women's Singles">Dubai</a>, losing to Venus in the last 4.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/Sony_Ericsson_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="Sony Ericsson Open">Sony Ericsson Open</a> Williams, hampered with ankle and quad injuries, was upset in the final by <a href="/wiki/Victoria_Azarenka" title="Victoria Azarenka">Victoria Azarenka</a>. This was the first of four consecutive losses for her, the longest losing streak of her career.<sup id="cite_ref-122" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-122">[122]</a></sup> She was defeated in her opening matches at <a href="/wiki/Andalucia_Tennis_Experience" title="Andalucia Tennis Experience">Barcelona</a>, <a href="/wiki/Internazionali_d%27Italia" class="mw-redirect" title="Internazionali d'Italia">Rome</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Mutua_Madrile%C3%B1a_Madrid_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open">Madrid</a>. Despite not having won a match on clay in 2009 before the French Open, she lost in the quarterfinals to the eventual champion Svetlana Kuznetsova. This ended her 18-match Grand Slam tournament winning streak. She rebounded at <a href="/wiki/2009_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2009 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles">Wimbledon</a>, saving a match point in defeating fourth seeded Dementieva in the semifinals. In the final, Serena defeated her sister Venus to win her third Wimbledon title and her 11th Grand Slam singles title.<sup id="cite_ref-123" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-123">[123]</a></sup> Serena and Venus teamed to win the women's doubles title at Wimbledon for the second consecutive year, their ninth Grand Slam title in women's doubles.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p> As a US Open preparation, Williams played at <a href="/wiki/Western_%26_Southern_Financial_Group_Women%27s_Open" class="mw-redirect" title="Western &amp; Southern Financial Group Women's Open">Cincinnati</a> losing in the third round, followed by a semifinal defeat at the Rogers Cup. At the US Open, she lost in the semifinals to eventual champion Kim Clijsters amid <a href="#2009_US_Open">controversy</a> involving shouting at a line judge when defending match point, an offense which cost Williams the point and consequently the match. She continued in the doubles competition, teaming up with Venus to win their third Grand Slam doubles title of the year and tenth of their career.<sup id="cite_ref-lat2009_124-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lat2009-124">[124]</a></sup> Williams won all three of her round-robin matches at the year-end <a href="/wiki/2009_WTA_Tour_Championships" title="2009 WTA Tour Championships">WTA Tour Championships</a>, defeating Venus, Dementieva, and Kuznetsova, saving a match point against Venus. She then advanced to the final, when Wozniacki retired from their semifinal match. In the final, Williams defeated Venus for her second singles title at this event.<sup id="cite_ref-125" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-125">[125]</a></sup> </p>
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Melbourne_Australian_Open_2010_Serena_Serve.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Melbourne_Australian_Open_2010_Serena_Serve.jpg/220px-Melbourne_Australian_Open_2010_Serena_Serve.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="321" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Melbourne_Australian_Open_2010_Serena_Serve.jpg/330px-Melbourne_Australian_Open_2010_Serena_Serve.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Melbourne_Australian_Open_2010_Serena_Serve.jpg/440px-Melbourne_Australian_Open_2010_Serena_Serve.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1179" data-file-height="1722"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Melbourne_Australian_Open_2010_Serena_Serve.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>
         <div style="text-align: center;">
          Williams on her way to the singles and doubles title at the 2010 Australian Open
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div>
      <p> Williams finished the year ranked No. 1 for the second time in her career, having played in 16 tournaments, more than any other year. She also broke the record previously set by Justine Henin for the most prize money earned by a female tennis player in one year, with Williams earning $6,545,586. For doubles that year, the Williams sisters finished the year ranked No. 2, despite playing only six tournaments together as a pair. Williams had won five Grand Slam tournament titles, putting her total of Grand Slam titles won thus far at 23, and she was consequently named Female Athlete of the Year by the Associated Press for 2009.<sup id="cite_ref-126" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-126">[126]</a></sup> Williams was also the <a href="/wiki/International_Tennis_Federation" title="International Tennis Federation">ITF</a> World Champion in both the singles and doubles events.<sup id="cite_ref-127" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-127">[127]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2010, Williams's first scheduled tournament was in <a href="/wiki/Medibank_International_Sydney" class="mw-redirect" title="Medibank International Sydney">Sydney</a>, losing in the final to Elena Dementieva. At the <a href="/wiki/2010_Australian_Open" title="2010 Australian Open">Australian Open</a>, Williams was the defending champion in both singles and doubles. She reached the final and defeated Justine Henin, who had just recently come out of retirement, for her twelfth Grand Slam singles title. In doubles, Williams and her sister, Venus, successfully defended their title by defeating <a href="/wiki/Cara_Black" title="Cara Black">Cara Black</a> and <a href="/wiki/Liezel_Huber" title="Liezel Huber">Liezel Huber</a> in the final.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams withdrew with a leg injury from her next few events,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (August 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> and returned at the <a href="/wiki/2010_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia" class="mw-redirect" title="2010 Internazionali BNL d'Italia">Rome Masters</a>, losing to Jelena Janković in the semifinals. At <a href="/wiki/2010_Mutua_Madrile%C3%B1a_Madrid_Open" title="2010 Mutua Madrileña Madrid Open">Madrid</a>, she fell to Nadia Petrova in the third round but partnered Venus to win the doubles title.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2010_French_Open" title="2010 French Open">French Open</a>, Williams was defeated by <a href="/wiki/Samantha_Stosur" title="Samantha Stosur">Samantha Stosur</a> in the quarterfinals. She and Venus were the top seeds in the doubles event and won the title, defeating <a href="/wiki/Kv%C4%9Bta_Peschke" title="Květa Peschke">Květa Peschke</a> and <a href="/wiki/Katarina_Srebotnik" title="Katarina Srebotnik">Katarina Srebotnik</a> in the final to win their fourth consecutive Grand Slam doubles title and improving their doubles ranking to No. 1.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams's next tournament was Wimbledon, where she defeated Russian Vera Zvonareva in the final without facing a break point and breaking the serve of Zvonareva three times.<sup id="cite_ref-NYTIMESW10_128-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTIMESW10-128">[128]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-TennisSW10_129-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TennisSW10-129">[129]</a></sup> She did not lose a set in the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-130" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-130">[130]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>After the match, Martina Navratilova said that Williams is in the top five of all the women's tennis players in all of history, which she said that "it's not just about how many Slams you win or how many tournaments you win—it's just your game overall. And she's got all the goods."<sup id="cite_ref-TennisSW10_129-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-TennisSW10-129">[129]</a></sup> Serena was the defending champion in doubles with her sister Venus, winning the last two years. They lost in the quarterfinals to <a href="/wiki/Elena_Vesnina" title="Elena Vesnina">Elena Vesnina</a> and Zvonareva. In Munich on July 7, Williams stepped on broken glass while in a restaurant, and the injury caused her to miss the rest of the year.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams ended the year ranked No. 4 in singles after six tournaments,<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> and No. 11 in doubles after four tournaments.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>On March 2, 2011, she confirmed that she had suffered a <a href="/wiki/Hematoma" title="Hematoma">hematoma</a> and a <a href="/wiki/Pulmonary_embolism" title="Pulmonary embolism">pulmonary embolism</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-131" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-131">[131]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-132" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-132">[132]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-133" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-133">[133]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2011.E2.80.932013:_Return_to_dominance.2C_career_golden_slam"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2011–2013:_Return_to_dominance,_career_golden_slam">2011–2013: Return to dominance, career golden slam</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=10" title="Edit section: 2011–2013: Return to dominance, career golden slam">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: 
       <a href="/wiki/2011_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2011 Serena Williams tennis season">2011</a>, 
       <a href="/wiki/2012_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2012 Serena Williams tennis season">2012</a>, and 
       <a href="/wiki/2013_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2013 Serena Williams tennis season">2013 Serena Williams tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams finally made a return to the practice court in March 2011.<sup id="cite_ref-134" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-134">[134]</a></sup> She made her first appearance on the WTA tour in almost a year in <a href="/wiki/2011_Aegon_International" title="2011 Aegon International">Eastbourne</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-135" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-135">[135]</a></sup> Williams lost in round two to Vera Zvonareva, in a match that lasted over three hours.<sup id="cite_ref-136" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-136">[136]</a></sup> Her next tournament was <a href="/wiki/2011_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2011 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a>, where she was the defending champion. She reached the round of 16, where she lost to <a href="/wiki/Marion_Bartoli" title="Marion Bartoli">Marion Bartoli</a>. After the loss her ranking dropped to 169. Williams won her first titles since her return to tennis triumphing in <a href="/wiki/2011_Bank_of_the_West_Classic" title="2011 Bank of the West Classic">Stanford</a> and <a href="/wiki/2011_Rogers_Cup" title="2011 Rogers Cup">Toronto</a>. At the <a href="/wiki/2011_Western_%26_Southern_Open" title="2011 Western &amp; Southern Open">Western &amp; Southern Open</a>, Williams defeated <a href="/wiki/Lucie_Hradeck%C3%A1" title="Lucie Hradecká">Lucie Hradecká</a>, only to withdraw the next day, citing a right toe injury. She then played at the <a href="/wiki/2011_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2011 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> going all the way to the final losing to Samantha Stosur, during a match which featured her <a href="#2011_US_Open">verbally abusing the chair umpire</a>. The US Open final turned out to be Williams's last match in 2011, and she ended the year ranked No. 12 with two titles and with a 22–3 record for the season. She only participated in six tournaments throughout the season. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Serena_Williams_wins_Gold_cropped.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Serena_Williams_wins_Gold_cropped.jpg/220px-Serena_Williams_wins_Gold_cropped.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="365" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Serena_Williams_wins_Gold_cropped.jpg/330px-Serena_Williams_wins_Gold_cropped.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Serena_Williams_wins_Gold_cropped.jpg/440px-Serena_Williams_wins_Gold_cropped.jpg 2x" data-file-width="800" data-file-height="1328"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Serena_Williams_wins_Gold_cropped.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>
         <div style="text-align: center;">
          Williams won the singles gold medal at the 2012 Olympic Games.
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams started the 2012 season at the <a href="/wiki/2012_Brisbane_International" title="2012 Brisbane International">Brisbane International</a>, however, during her match against <a href="/wiki/Bojana_Jovanovski" class="mw-redirect" title="Bojana Jovanovski">Bojana Jovanovski</a>, she injured her left ankle when serving for the match. As a result, Williams was forced to withdraw from the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-137" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-137">[137]</a></sup> Next she participated at the <a href="/wiki/2012_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2012 Australian Open – Women's Singles">Australian Open</a> where she was upset by <a href="/wiki/Ekaterina_Makarova" title="Ekaterina Makarova">Ekaterina Makarova</a> in the fourth round. After a month layoff, Williams returned to competition in <a href="/wiki/2012_Sony_Ericsson_Open" title="2012 Sony Ericsson Open">Miami</a> losing in the quarterfinals to Caroline Wozniacki. Williams then won consecutive titles at <a href="/wiki/2012_Family_Circle_Cup" title="2012 Family Circle Cup">Charleston</a> and <a href="/wiki/2012_Mutua_Madrid_Open" title="2012 Mutua Madrid Open">Madrid</a> beating <a href="/wiki/Lucie_%C5%A0af%C3%A1%C5%99ov%C3%A1" title="Lucie Šafářová">Lucie Šafářová</a> and Victoria Azarenka, but withdrew from her semifinal match against <a href="/wiki/Li_Na_(tennis)" class="mw-redirect" title="Li Na (tennis)">Li Na</a> in <a href="/wiki/2012_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia" class="mw-redirect" title="2012 Internazionali BNL d'Italia">Rome</a> citing a lower back injury. Williams suffered her first ever loss in the opening round of a Grand Slam tournament at the French Open against <a href="/wiki/Virginie_Razzano" title="Virginie Razzano">Virginie Razzano</a>. Williams notched up a 33–1 record for the second half of the season winning five titles in the process.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_2012_138-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_2012-138">[138]</a></sup> Williams won her fifth <a href="/wiki/2012_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2012 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a> singles title, her fourteenth Grand Slam title;<sup id="cite_ref-139" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-139">[139]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-140" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-140">[140]</a></sup> setting a serving record of 24 aces by a female in a match as well as having the most aces, male or female, during the tournament (102).<sup id="cite_ref-141" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-141">[141]</a></sup> Williams returned to America to successfully defend her title in <a href="/wiki/2012_Bank_of_the_West_Classic" title="2012 Bank of the West Classic">Stanford</a> beating <a href="/wiki/CoCo_Vandeweghe" title="CoCo Vandeweghe">CoCo Vandeweghe</a> in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-142" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-142">[142]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-huffingtonpost.com_143-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-huffingtonpost.com-143">[143]</a></sup> Williams then returned to Wimbledon to represent her country at the Olympic Games where she won gold, defeating Maria Sharapova in a dominating performance. Williams failed to drop more than three games per set en route to winning the medal.<sup id="cite_ref-huffingtonpost.com_143-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-huffingtonpost.com-143">[143]</a></sup> Williams undefeated streak ended with a loss in Cincinnati to <a href="/wiki/Angelique_Kerber" title="Angelique Kerber">Angelique Kerber</a>. In New York City, Williams went on to win her fourth <a href="/wiki/2012_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2012 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> singles title and her 15th career Grand Slam title overall beating Azarenka in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_2012_138-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_2012-138">[138]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-144" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-144">[144]</a></sup> Williams ended the season by competing at the WTA Championships and went undefeated throughout the tournament to win the event for her third title.<sup id="cite_ref-BBC_2012_138-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-BBC_2012-138">[138]</a></sup> Williams was voted WTA Player of the Year for the fourth time.<sup id="cite_ref-145" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-145">[145]</a></sup> Based on her brilliant show in 2012, Williams was also named <a href="/wiki/International_Tennis_Federation" title="International Tennis Federation">International Tennis Federation</a> World Champion.<sup id="cite_ref-146" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-146">[146]</a></sup> Williams also returned to doubles competitions with Venus; in the pair's first tournament since <a href="/wiki/2010_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2010 Wimbledon Championships">2010 Wimbledon</a>, they claimed their fifth Wimbledon doubles title and the 13th grand slam doubles title.<sup id="cite_ref-147" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-147">[147]</a></sup> The pair successfully defended their Olympic doubles title which meant that they became the only tennis players to win four gold medals.<sup id="cite_ref-CBS-Olympic_6-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-CBS-Olympic-6">[6]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams's first tournament of the 2013 season was in <a href="/wiki/2013_Brisbane_International" title="2013 Brisbane International">Brisbane</a>, where she won the title without dropping a set. Williams was upset in the quarterfinals of the <a href="/wiki/2013_Australian_Open" title="2013 Australian Open">Australian Open</a> by fellow American player <a href="/wiki/Sloane_Stephens" title="Sloane Stephens">Sloane Stephens</a>. By virtue of defeating <a href="/wiki/Petra_Kvitov%C3%A1" title="Petra Kvitová">Petra Kvitová</a> in Doha, Williams returned to the No. 1 position for the sixth time in her career and became the oldest woman in the Open Era to hold the ranking.<sup id="cite_ref-148" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-148">[148]</a></sup> Williams went on to lose to Victoria Azarenka in the final. In the Miami final, Williams lost a set to Maria Sharapova for the first time since 2008. This setback did not stop Williams who recorded her 70th come-from-behind win. The win made Williams a six-time champion in Miami breaking the record she held with Steffi Graf and became only the fourth woman in the Open Era to have won a tournament at least six times.<sup id="cite_ref-149" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-149">[149]</a></sup> Williams successfully defended her Charleston title, winning it for the third time overall.<sup id="cite_ref-150" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-150">[150]</a></sup> Williams won her fiftieth career singles title in <a href="/wiki/2013_Mutua_Madrid_Open" title="2013 Mutua Madrid Open">Madrid</a>, defeating Sharapova in the final. Williams then played Rome, where she won the title without dropping a set, defeating Victoria Azarenka in the final to take her second title. Williams only dropped ten games in reaching the quarterfinals at Roland Garros. There, she played Svetlana Kuznetsova and lost her first set of the tournament. In the semifinal Williams only lost one game when she defeated Sara Errani, something seven-time French Open champion Chris Evert described as the finest female performance on clay she had ever seen.<sup id="cite_ref-151" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-151">[151]</a></sup> Williams defeated Sharapova to claim her second Roland Garros title, her sixteenth grand slam tournament title overall. She became the fourth woman in the Open Era after Navratilova, Evert and Graf to win each Grand Slam tournament title on at least two occasions. At <a href="/wiki/2013_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2013 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a>, she advanced easily to the fourth round before being upset by eventual finalist <a href="/wiki/Sabine_Lisicki" title="Sabine Lisicki">Sabine Lisicki</a> in three sets. After Wimbledon, Williams won the Swedish Open by defeating <a href="/wiki/Johanna_Larsson_(tennis)" class="mw-redirect" title="Johanna Larsson (tennis)">Johanna Larsson</a> in the final, the tournament win marked the first occasion that she had won an <a href="/wiki/WTA_International_tournaments" title="WTA International tournaments">International</a> level title. By winning the tournament this meant that Williams had managed to be undefeated on clay during the season.<sup id="cite_ref-152" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-152">[152]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:302px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Serena_Williams_serves_at_the_US_Open_(9665931630).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Serena_Williams_serves_at_the_US_Open_%289665931630%29.jpg/300px-Serena_Williams_serves_at_the_US_Open_%289665931630%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="300" height="200" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Serena_Williams_serves_at_the_US_Open_%289665931630%29.jpg/450px-Serena_Williams_serves_at_the_US_Open_%289665931630%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Serena_Williams_serves_at_the_US_Open_%289665931630%29.jpg/600px-Serena_Williams_serves_at_the_US_Open_%289665931630%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="4039" data-file-height="2693"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Serena_Williams_serves_at_the_US_Open_(9665931630).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>
         <div style="text-align: center;">
          Williams winning her fifth US Open title
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams won her 3rd Rogers Cup title in Toronto beating <a href="/wiki/Sorana_C%C3%AErstea" title="Sorana Cîrstea">Sorana Cîrstea</a> in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-153" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-153">[153]</a></sup> Williams reached the final of the <a href="/wiki/2013_Western_%26_Southern_Open" title="2013 Western &amp; Southern Open">Western &amp; Southern Open</a> for the first time but lost to Azarenka.<sup id="cite_ref-154" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-154">[154]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2013_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2013 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, Williams began as top seed and defending champion. She reached the final—rematch of the 2012 final against Azarenka—and won in three sets, capturing her 17th Grand Slam singles title.<sup id="cite_ref-usopen_155-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-usopen-155">[155]</a></sup> Williams became the oldest US Open champion in the Open Era and pushed her career prize money past $50<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>million.<sup id="cite_ref-usopen_155-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-usopen-155">[155]</a></sup> After the US Open, Williams beat Jelena Janković to win the China Open in Beijing for her 10th title of 2013.<sup id="cite_ref-156" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-156">[156]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-157" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-157">[157]</a></sup> Williams went through the WTA Championships undefeated winning the final against Li Na, to become the first person to defend the title since Justine Henin in 2007. Williams won her 11th title of 2013 becoming the 8th player to win 11 titles or more in a year and the first since Martina Hingis in 1997.<sup id="cite_ref-158" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-158">[158]</a></sup> Also, she became the oldest person to win the WTA Championships and 4th player to win it 4 times or more. By winning the championship, Williams became the first woman to win more than $10<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>million in a season and with her total of $12,385,572, only <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Nadal" title="Rafael Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a>, in 2013, and <a href="/wiki/Novak_Djokovic" title="Novak Djokovic">Novak Djokovic</a>, in 2011, 2012 and 2013, have earned more money in one season.<sup id="cite_ref-159" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-159">[159]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams finished as the year end No. 1 for the third time, becoming the oldest No. 1 player in WTA history.<sup id="cite_ref-160" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-160">[160]</a></sup> She was also named the 2013 ITF World Champion, the fourth time that she has been given the World Champion's crown.<sup id="cite_ref-161" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-161">[161]</a></sup> Williams received two prizes at the <a href="/wiki/2013_ESPY_Awards" title="2013 ESPY Awards">2013 ESPY Awards</a>. Williams won Best Female Athlete and Best Female Tennis Player. Williams is just the fourth person to win Best Female Athlete on two occasions and she won Best Female Tennis player for a record sixth time.<sup id="cite_ref-162" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-162">[162]</a></sup> In late December 2013, Williams capped off her year by receiving the Associated Press 2013 Female Athlete of the Year award, her third AP award after 2002 and 2009. Only two women, Chris Evert and <a href="/wiki/Babe_Didrikson" class="mw-redirect" title="Babe Didrikson">Babe Didrikson</a>, have been chosen more often as AP Athlete of the Year since the annual awards were first handed out in 1931.<sup id="cite_ref-163" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-163">[163]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span id="2014.E2.80.932015:_Second_.27Serena_Slam.27"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2014–2015:_Second_'Serena_Slam'">2014–2015: Second 'Serena Slam'</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=11" title="Edit section: 2014–2015: Second 'Serena Slam'">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main articles: 
       <a href="/wiki/2014_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2014 Serena Williams tennis season">2014</a> and 
       <a href="/wiki/2015_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2015 Serena Williams tennis season">2015 Serena Williams tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams defended her title at the <a href="/wiki/2014_Brisbane_International" title="2014 Brisbane International">Brisbane International</a> by defeating No. 2, Victoria Azarenka, in the final.<sup id="cite_ref-164" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-164">[164]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2014_Australian_Open" title="2014 Australian Open">Australian Open</a> she ended up losing to former No. 1, Ana Ivanovic, in the fourth round. At <a href="/wiki/2014_Dubai_Tennis_Championships" title="2014 Dubai Tennis Championships">Dubai</a>, Williams lost her semifinal match to <a href="/wiki/Aliz%C3%A9_Cornet" title="Alizé Cornet">Alizé Cornet</a> in straight sets. Williams next headed to the Miami Open where she won her record seventh title with a straight-sets victory over No. 2 <a href="/wiki/Li_Na" title="Li Na">Li Na</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-165" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-165">[165]</a></sup> Williams lost to <a href="/wiki/Jana_%C4%8Cepelov%C3%A1" title="Jana Čepelová">Jana Čepelová</a> in the second round of the <a href="/wiki/2014_Family_Circle_Cup" title="2014 Family Circle Cup">Family Circle Cup</a>. She made it to the quarterfinals at the <a href="/wiki/2014_Mutua_Madrid_Open" title="2014 Mutua Madrid Open">Madrid Open</a> before withdrawing with a left thigh injury. Williams won her third title of the season at the <a href="/wiki/2014_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia" class="mw-redirect" title="2014 Internazionali BNL d'Italia">Rome</a>. She was then handed the worst loss of her Grand Slam tournament career by <a href="/wiki/Garbi%C3%B1e_Muguruza" title="Garbiñe Muguruza">Garbiñe Muguruza</a> at the second round of the <a href="/wiki/2014_French_Open" title="2014 French Open">French Open</a>, who defeated Serena losing just four games in two sets.<sup id="cite_ref-166" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-166">[166]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Aliz%C3%A9_Cornet" title="Alizé Cornet">Alizé Cornet</a> defeated Williams for the second time in the year in the third round of <a href="/wiki/2014_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2014 Wimbledon Championships">Wimbledon</a>, thus handing Williams her earliest Wimbledon exit since 2005. Serena was then forced to withdraw from the doubles event alongside sister Venus while trailing 0–3 in the second round. A disoriented Serena hit 4 consecutive doubles faults and was having trouble with both her ball toss and movement before being removed from what has been described as one of the most unusual scenes ever seen in tennis.<sup id="cite_ref-167" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-167">[167]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-168" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-168">[168]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams rebounded by winning 19 out of her next 20 matches (losing only to sister Venus in the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/2014_Rogers_Cup" title="2014 Rogers Cup">Rogers Cup</a>). This streak include titles at the <a href="/wiki/2014_Bank_of_the_West_Classic" title="2014 Bank of the West Classic">Bank of the West Classic</a> as well as her first <a href="/wiki/2014_Western_%26_Southern_Open" title="2014 Western &amp; Southern Open">Western &amp; Southern Open</a> title and her third consecutive and sixth overall <a href="/wiki/2014_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2014 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> singles title which she won without having dropped a set.<sup id="cite_ref-169" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-169">[169]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-170" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-170">[170]</a></sup> With this victory Williams tied Chris Evert for most singles titles won by a woman at the US Open in the Open Era. Williams also tied Evert and Navratilova's 18 Grand Slam singles titles won in the Open Era. By virtue of having won both the <a href="/wiki/2014_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2014 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> and the <a href="/wiki/2014_US_Open_Series" title="2014 US Open Series">US Open Series</a>, Williams collected $4,000,000 – the biggest payday in tennis history. At the <a href="/wiki/2014_Wuhan_Open" title="2014 Wuhan Open">Wuhan Open</a> a viral illness forced her to retire while up a break in the first set against <a href="/wiki/Aliz%C3%A9_Cornet" title="Alizé Cornet">Alizé Cornet</a>. Cornet thus became the first woman since Justine Henin in <a href="/wiki/2007_WTA_Tour" title="2007 WTA Tour">2007</a> to record three victories over Williams in one year. At the <a href="/wiki/2014_China_Open_(tennis)" title="2014 China Open (tennis)">China Open</a> Williams retired prior to her quarterfinal match versus Samantha Stosur. At the <a href="/wiki/2014_WTA_Finals" title="2014 WTA Finals">2014 WTA Finals</a> in Singapore Williams advanced to the final for the third consecutive year despite having equaled her career worst loss in her second round robin match versus <a href="/wiki/Simona_Halep" title="Simona Halep">Simona Halep</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-171" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-171">[171]</a></sup> Williams won her fifth <a href="/wiki/WTA_Finals" title="WTA Finals">WTA Finals</a> title by avenging her loss to Halep in the championship match for her seventh title of the year.<sup id="cite_ref-172" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-172">[172]</a></sup> Williams finished the year ranked No. 1 for the fourth time in her career. She held the No. 1 ranking for the entire calendar year, a feat not accomplished since Steffi Graf in 1996. She was also voted WTA Player of the Year and ITF World Champion for a third consecutive year (sixth overall).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams began the <a href="/wiki/2015_WTA_Tour" title="2015 WTA Tour">2015 season</a> by representing the <a href="/wiki/United_States_at_the_Hopman_Cup" title="United States at the Hopman Cup">United States</a> alongside <a href="/wiki/John_Isner" title="John Isner">John Isner</a> at the <a href="/wiki/2015_Hopman_Cup" title="2015 Hopman Cup">Hopman Cup</a>. The American pair lost the final to the Poland.<sup id="cite_ref-173" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-173">[173]</a></sup> At the <a href="/wiki/2015_Australian_Open" title="2015 Australian Open">Australian Open</a> Williams defeated Maria Sharapova for the 16th consecutive time to claim her 6th Australian Open singles title and 19th career Grand Slam singles title, winning the title on her third match point in the second set.<sup id="cite_ref-174" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-174">[174]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-175" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-175">[175]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-176" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-176">[176]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-177" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-177">[177]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-178" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-178">[178]</a></sup> With this victory Williams surpassed both, Evert and Navratilova, for <a href="/wiki/List_of_Grand_Slam_women%27s_singles_champions" title="List of Grand Slam women's singles champions">second most Grand Slam singles titles won</a> in the Open Era. The title was also her sixth Grand Slam singles title since turning 30 years of age, three more than the next closest to do so (Margaret Court, Martina Navratilova with three each). She is the only player in history to win all four Grand Slams at least once after having turned 30. The following weekend, Serena and sister Venus traveled to Buenos Aires to face Argentina in a World Group II tie for <a href="/wiki/Fed_Cup" title="Fed Cup">Fed Cup</a>. She played and won her only match against <a href="/wiki/Mar%C3%ADa_Irigoyen" title="María Irigoyen">María Irigoyen</a> to help Team USA to a 4–1 win over Argentina.<sup id="cite_ref-179" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-179">[179]</a></sup> Williams announced that she would be competing at the <a href="/wiki/2015_BNP_Paribas_Open" title="2015 BNP Paribas Open">Indian Wells Masters</a> ending her 14-year boycott of the event.<sup id="cite_ref-NYT20150205_180-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYT20150205-180">[180]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-181" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-181">[181]</a></sup> Upon her return Williams received a standing ovation from the crowd and won her first match in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-182" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-182">[182]</a></sup> She reached the semifinals, where she was due to face No. 3, <a href="/wiki/Simona_Halep" title="Simona Halep">Simona Halep</a>, for a place in the final, but was forced to withdraw because of a knee injury. By virtue of having defeated Sabine Lisicki in the quarterfinals of the <a href="/wiki/2015_Miami_Open" title="2015 Miami Open">Miami Open</a>, Williams became only the eighth woman in the Open Era to record 700 match wins in her career.<sup id="cite_ref-183" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-183">[183]</a></sup> This also made her one of only three active players to have won 700 or more matches in singles, others being <a href="/wiki/Roger_Federer" title="Roger Federer">Roger Federer</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rafael_Nadal" title="Rafael Nadal">Rafael Nadal</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-184" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-184">[184]</a></sup> In the semifinals she won against Halep to advance to her tenth final at the event<sup id="cite_ref-185" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-185">[185]</a></sup> where she won a record eighth title and extended her winning streak to 21 by beating <a href="/wiki/Carla_Su%C3%A1rez_Navarro" title="Carla Suárez Navarro">Carla Suárez Navarro</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-186" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-186">[186]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-187" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-187">[187]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-188" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-188">[188]</a></sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Serena_Williams_Won_Roland_Garros_in_2015.JPG" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Serena_Williams_Won_Roland_Garros_in_2015.JPG/220px-Serena_Williams_Won_Roland_Garros_in_2015.JPG" decoding="async" width="220" height="284" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Serena_Williams_Won_Roland_Garros_in_2015.JPG/330px-Serena_Williams_Won_Roland_Garros_in_2015.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Serena_Williams_Won_Roland_Garros_in_2015.JPG/440px-Serena_Williams_Won_Roland_Garros_in_2015.JPG 2x" data-file-width="1360" data-file-height="1756"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Serena_Williams_Won_Roland_Garros_in_2015.JPG" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>
         <div style="text-align: center;">
          Williams celebrating her third French Open title
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>As preparation for the clay court season (and to ensure her eligibility for the 2016 Summer Olympics), Williams travelled to <a href="/wiki/Brindisi,_Italy" class="mw-redirect" title="Brindisi, Italy">Brindisi, Italy</a>, to face Italy's team for a place in the <a href="/wiki/Fed_Cup" title="Fed Cup">Fed Cup</a>'s World Group. Williams lost the decisive doubles match alongside <a href="/wiki/Alison_Riske" title="Alison Riske">Alison Riske</a> to Sara Errani and Flavia Pennetta, and as a result the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Fed_Cup_team" title="United States Fed Cup team">United States team</a> were relegated to World Group II. It was Williams's first loss in the Fed Cup.<sup id="cite_ref-189" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-189">[189]</a></sup> She maintained her perfect record in singles by defeating <a href="/wiki/Camila_Giorgi" title="Camila Giorgi">Camila Giorgi</a> and Errani. The week of April 20 marked Williams's 114th consecutive week ranked No. 1, the third-longest run in WTA history, behind Steffi Graf's 186 weeks and Navratilova's 156.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (November 2015)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Williams suffered her first defeat of the season in the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/2015_Mutua_Madrid_Open" title="2015 Mutua Madrid Open">Mutua Madrid Open</a> to No. 4, Petra Kvitová.<sup id="cite_ref-190" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-190">[190]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-191" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-191">[191]</a></sup> This loss ended a 27-match winning streak for Williams as well as a 50-match winning streak at <a href="/wiki/WTA_Premier_tournaments" title="WTA Premier tournaments">Premier-Mandatory events</a>, and also a 19-match winning streak at the particular event.<sup id="cite_ref-192" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-192">[192]</a></sup> Williams played one match at the 2015 <a href="/wiki/2015_Internazionali_BNL_d%27Italia" class="mw-redirect" title="2015 Internazionali BNL d'Italia">Internazionali BNL d'Italia</a> before withdrawing from the tournament with an elbow injury.<sup id="cite_ref-193" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-193">[193]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>By virtue of having defeated Victoria Azarenka in the third round of the <a href="/wiki/2015_French_Open" title="2015 French Open">French Open</a>, Williams became the first woman in the Open Era to win 50 matches at all four of the Grand Slams.<sup id="cite_ref-194" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-194">[194]</a></sup> Williams then defeated <a href="/wiki/Sloane_Stephens" title="Sloane Stephens">Sloane Stephens</a> to reach her 40th Grand Slam singles quarterfinal.<sup id="cite_ref-195" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-195">[195]</a></sup> Williams won her next match easily, but had to come back from a set down in the semifinals versus <a href="/wiki/Timea_Bacsinszky" title="Timea Bacsinszky">Timea Bacsinszky</a> for the fourth time in five matches to reach the final.<sup id="cite_ref-196" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-196">[196]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-197" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-197">[197]</a></sup> She would go on to defeat <a href="/wiki/Lucie_%C5%A0af%C3%A1%C5%99ov%C3%A1" title="Lucie Šafářová">Lucie Šafářová</a> from the <a href="/wiki/Czech_Republic" title="Czech Republic">Czech Republic</a> in three sets to win her third French Open and 20th Grand Slam singles title.<sup id="cite_ref-198" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-198">[198]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-199" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-199">[199]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-200" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-200">[200]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The win made Williams only the third person in history to win each Grand Slam at least three times, joining Margaret Court and Steffi Graf. She is the first player to win three straight Grand Slams since she did it herself during the Serena Slam. She also became the first player to win the Australian-French Open double since Jennifer Capriati in 2001.<sup id="cite_ref-201" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-201">[201]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams completed her second "Serena Slam" (winning all four Grand Slams in a row) by winning the <a href="/wiki/2015_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2015 Wimbledon Championships">2015 Wimbledon Championships</a> – her 6th Wimbledon and 21st <a href="/wiki/Grand_Slam_(tennis)" title="Grand Slam (tennis)">Grand Slam</a> singles title overall.<sup id="cite_ref-202" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-202">[202]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-203" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-203">[203]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-204" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-204">[204]</a></sup> Her path to victory at Wimbledon was particularly challenging. She was down a double break in the third round versus <a href="/wiki/Heather_Watson" title="Heather Watson">Heather Watson</a> and two points from defeat twice before rallying for the win<sup id="cite_ref-205" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-205">[205]</a></sup> and becoming the first player to qualify for the <a href="/wiki/2015_WTA_Finals" title="2015 WTA Finals">WTA Finals</a><sup id="cite_ref-206" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-206">[206]</a></sup> (the earliest that a player had qualified since the event switched to the round-robin format in 2003). Williams then defeated three <a href="/wiki/List_of_WTA_number_1_ranked_players" class="mw-redirect" title="List of WTA number 1 ranked players">former No. 1 players</a>–Venus Williams, Victoria Azarenka and Maria Sharapova—in succession to advance to the final.<sup id="cite_ref-207" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-207">[207]</a></sup> Awaiting her there was 21-year-old Garbiñe Muguruza, who had previously handed Williams the worst Grand Slam tournament defeat of her career at the 2014 French Open.<sup id="cite_ref-208" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-208">[208]</a></sup> Williams defeated Muguruza in a tight two-setter.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>The victory made Williams the oldest woman in the Open Era to win a grand slam singles title, in addition to having the distinction of being the oldest ladies' grand slam singles champion of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-209" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-209">[209]</a></sup> It also was her eighth consecutive victory in Grand Slam singles finals appearances, <a href="/wiki/Steffi_Graf_career_statistics" title="Steffi Graf career statistics">breaking Steffi Graf's Open Era record of seven</a> from 1995 through 1999 and, on the men's side, <a href="/wiki/Pete_Sampras_career_statistics" title="Pete Sampras career statistics">tying Pete Sampras's Open Era record of eight</a> from 1995 through 2000. Her 21st Grand Slam singles titles equaled the tally of the rest of the women's tour, combined.<sup id="cite_ref-210" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-210">[210]</a></sup> The week of July 13 marked the first time in WTA history that the No. 1 player had more than twice as many points as No. 2.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceB_211-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceB-211">[211]</a></sup> Following her win at Wimbledon, Williams was awarded her 7th <a href="/wiki/ESPY_Award" title="ESPY Award">ESPY</a> for <a href="/wiki/Best_Female_Tennis_Player_ESPY_Award" title="Best Female Tennis Player ESPY Award">Best Female Tennis Player</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-212" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-212">[212]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams played one match at the <a href="/wiki/2015_Swedish_Open" title="2015 Swedish Open">Swedish Open</a> in <a href="/wiki/B%C3%A5stad" title="Båstad">Båstad</a> before withdrawing with an elbow injury.<sup id="cite_ref-213" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-213">[213]</a></sup> She was the defending champion at the <a href="/wiki/2015_Bank_of_the_West_Classic" title="2015 Bank of the West Classic">Bank of the West Classic</a> but withdrew from the tournament in order for her elbow to get better.<sup id="cite_ref-214" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-214">[214]</a></sup> Williams had her 19 match winning streak ended by 18-year-old Swiss <a href="/wiki/Belinda_Bencic" title="Belinda Bencic">Belinda Bencic</a>, the No. 20, in three tight sets in the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/2015_Rogers_Cup" title="2015 Rogers Cup">Canadian Open</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-215" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-215">[215]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-216" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-216">[216]</a></sup> It was her second defeat of the year and first on hard courts since the 2014 WTA Finals. The next week Williams defended her title at the <a href="/wiki/2015_Western_%26_Southern_Open" title="2015 Western &amp; Southern Open">Western &amp; Southern Open</a> with a straight sets victory over No. 3 Simona Halep for her 69th WTA title, breaking a tie with <a href="/wiki/Evonne_Goolagong" class="mw-redirect" title="Evonne Goolagong">Evonne Goolagong</a> for standalone fifth-most WTA titles won.<sup id="cite_ref-217" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-217">[217]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-218" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-218">[218]</a></sup> Williams's attempt at capturing the "Grand Slam" (winning all four Grand Slams in a calendar year) came to an end in the semifinals of the <a href="/wiki/2015_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2015 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>, where she lost to Roberta Vinci in three sets.<sup id="cite_ref-219" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-219">[219]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-220" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-220">[220]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-221" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-221">[221]</a></sup> The loss has been described by some as one of the biggest upsets in tennis history.<sup id="cite_ref-222" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-222">[222]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-223" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-223">[223]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-224" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-224">[224]</a></sup> Nonetheless, Williams secured the year-end No. 1 ranking with her results at the tournament.<sup id="cite_ref-225" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-225">[225]</a></sup> On October 1, Williams called an end to her season, stating that she had been injured for most of the year and wanted to address her fitness issues.<sup id="cite_ref-226" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-226">[226]</a></sup> Prior to the announcement, coach <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Mouratoglou" title="Patrick Mouratoglou">Patrick Mouratoglou</a> hinted that Williams might not play again in 2015 due to a lack of motivation and disappointment following her loss at the <a href="/wiki/2015_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2015 US Open (tennis)">Open</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-227" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-227">[227]</a></sup> On October 5, Williams surpassed Chris Evert for <a href="/wiki/List_of_WTA_number_1_ranked_players" class="mw-redirect" title="List of WTA number 1 ranked players">third-most weeks ranked world No. 1</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-228" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-228">[228]</a></sup> Williams held the No. 1 ranking the entire season for the second consecutive year, finishing there for the fifth time in her career. She was voted <a href="/wiki/WTA_Awards" title="WTA Awards">WTA Player of the Year</a> for the seventh time in her career.<sup id="cite_ref-229" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-229">[229]</a></sup> On December 14, <a href="/wiki/Sports_Illustrated" title="Sports Illustrated">Sports Illustrated</a> announced Williams as their <a href="/wiki/Sports_Illustrated_Sportsperson_of_the_Year" title="Sports Illustrated Sportsperson of the Year">Sportsperson of the Year</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-SISPOTY2015_230-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SISPOTY2015-230">[230]</a></sup> She thus became the third solo woman, and first since 1983, to receive the award.<sup id="cite_ref-231" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-231">[231]</a></sup> Williams was also named <a href="/wiki/ITF_World_Champions" title="ITF World Champions">ITF World Champion</a> for the sixth time in her career.<sup id="cite_ref-232" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-232">[232]</a></sup> Soon after, it was announced that she was voted <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press_Athlete_of_the_Year" title="Associated Press Athlete of the Year">Female Athlete of the Year</a> by the <a href="/wiki/Associated_Press" title="Associated Press">Associated Press</a> for the fourth time.<sup id="cite_ref-233" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-233">[233]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2016:_Open_Era_Grand_Slam_record">2016: Open Era Grand Slam record</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=12" title="Edit section: 2016: Open Era Grand Slam record">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <table class="box-BLP_sources_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-BLP_sources" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">

           <span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help by adding <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources">reliable sources</a>.            <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">July 2016</span>)</i></small>
           <small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>

      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2016_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2016 Serena Williams tennis season">2016 Serena Williams tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams withdrew from the <a href="/wiki/2016_Hopman_Cup" title="2016 Hopman Cup">Hopman Cup</a> after retiring from her singles match against <a href="/wiki/Australia_at_the_Hopman_Cup" title="Australia at the Hopman Cup">Australia Gold</a> with inflammation of her left knee.<sup id="cite_ref-234" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-234">[234]</a></sup> Her next tournament was the <a href="/wiki/2016_Australian_Open" title="2016 Australian Open">Australian Open</a>, where she was the No. 1 seed and defending champion. She reached the final without dropping a set, including wins over No. 5, Maria Sharapova, and No. 4, Agnieszka Radwańska, and faced first time Grand Slam finalist <a href="/wiki/Angelique_Kerber" title="Angelique Kerber">Angelique Kerber</a>. She was considered the heavy favorite to win the title, as she had never lost an Australian Open final or semifinal. She also dominated the head-to-head against Kerber, having lost only once in six meetings and having not lost a set to her in four years. Williams lost the final in three sets and Kerber won her first Grand Slam title.<sup id="cite_ref-235" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-235">[235]</a></sup> This marked Williams's first-ever loss in the final of the Australian Open, as well as her first three-set loss in the final of a Grand Slam.<sup id="cite_ref-236" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-236">[236]</a></sup> She had previously been 6–0 and 8–0 respectively. </p> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Williams_S._WM16_(20)_(28339693721).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Williams_S._WM16_%2820%29_%2828339693721%29.jpg/220px-Williams_S._WM16_%2820%29_%2828339693721%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="332" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Williams_S._WM16_%2820%29_%2828339693721%29.jpg/330px-Williams_S._WM16_%2820%29_%2828339693721%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ea/Williams_S._WM16_%2820%29_%2828339693721%29.jpg/440px-Williams_S._WM16_%2820%29_%2828339693721%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1526" data-file-height="2304"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Williams_S._WM16_(20)_(28339693721).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Serena at the 2016 Wimbledon, winning her 22nd Grand Slam title
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>The week of February 15 marked Williams's 157th consecutive week ranked No. 1, passing Navratilova's mark of 156 to have the second-longest run in WTA history behind Steffi Graf's 186. She competed in <a href="/wiki/2016_BNP_Paribas_Open" title="2016 BNP Paribas Open">Indian Wells</a> as the No. 1 seed. She reached her first final here since winning in 2001 and before boycotting the event, by defeating Simona Halep in the quarterfinals and Agnieszka Radwańska in the semifinals. She did not drop a set en route to the final. Williams was upset by No. 13 seed Victoria Azarenka, whom she had defeated the last five times the pair had met, in straight sets. This marked the first time since 2004 where Williams lost two consecutive finals. She next played the <a href="/wiki/2016_Miami_Open" title="2016 Miami Open">Miami Open</a> as the defending champion. She lost in the fourth round to Svetlana Kuznetsova. This marked her first loss here since 2012 and ended her 20 match winning streak in Miami. This was also her earliest exit here since 2000, where she lost in the same round. During the clay court swing, Williams withdrew from Madrid but entered Rome. She beat <a href="/wiki/Anna-Lena_Friedsam" title="Anna-Lena Friedsam">Anna-Lena Friedsam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christina_McHale" title="Christina McHale">Christina McHale</a> to progress to the quarterfinals where she defeated Svetlana Kuznetsova to avenge her loss in Miami. She then went on to beat <a href="/wiki/Irina-Camelia_Begu" title="Irina-Camelia Begu">Irina-Camelia Begu</a> and <a href="/wiki/Madison_Keys" title="Madison Keys">Madison Keys</a> to win her 70th career WTA title and to win her first title of the year. This was her third Rome title in four years and fourth overall.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/2016_French_Open" title="2016 French Open">French Open</a>, Williams dropped only one set en route to the final. She defeated <a href="/wiki/Yulia_Putintseva" title="Yulia Putintseva">Yulia Putintseva</a> in the quarterfinals despite being five points away from losing. She then beat surprise semifinalist <a href="/wiki/Kiki_Bertens" title="Kiki Bertens">Kiki Bertens</a> to reach her fourth French Open final where she faced Garbiñe Muguruza in a repeat of last year's Wimbledon final where Williams was victorious. The result was not the same as that Wimbledon final as Williams lost to Muguruza in straight sets. With this loss, Williams had lost two consecutive Grand Slam finals for the first time in her career. On top of failing to equal Steffi Graf's Open Era record of 22 Grand Slam singles titles, Williams also completed the Career Grand Slam runner-up set with this loss.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At <a href="/wiki/2016_Wimbledon" class="mw-redirect" title="2016 Wimbledon">Wimbledon</a>, Williams only lost one set en route to the final where she faced Angelique Kerber in a rematch of their Australian Open final earlier in the year. This time, Williams defeated Kerber in straight sets to finally equal Steffi Graf's record of 22 Grand Slams in the Open Era. That was Williams's first Grand Slam title of the year, as well as her 71st career WTA title overall. In what was a brilliant serving performance, Williams only faced one break point in the whole match against Kerber which she saved with an ace. Later that day, Williams partnered with sister Venus to win their sixth Wimbledon doubles title and 14th doubles Grand Slam title overall, keeping their perfect record at Grand Slam doubles finals intact. On July 24, 2016, Williams withdrew from <a href="/wiki/2016_Rogers_Cup" title="2016 Rogers Cup">Rogers Cup</a> citing a shoulder inflammation injury.<sup id="cite_ref-237" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-237">[237]</a></sup> She next participated in the <a href="/wiki/2016_Summer_Olympics" title="2016 Summer Olympics">Olympics</a> in <a href="/wiki/Rio_de_Janeiro" title="Rio de Janeiro">Rio de Janeiro</a>, where she was the defending gold medalist in both singles and doubles and was the heavy favourite to retain those titles. Partnering with her sister Venus in the doubles, they suffered a shock exit in the first round, losing to the Czech duo of Lucie Šafářová and Barbora Strýcová, which ended their career record of 15–0 dating back to the <a href="/wiki/Tennis_at_the_2000_Summer_Olympics_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_doubles" title="Tennis at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Women's doubles">2000 Olympics</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-238" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-238">[238]</a></sup> In singles, after defeating <a href="/wiki/Daria_Gavrilova" title="Daria Gavrilova">Daria Gavrilova</a> and <a href="/wiki/Aliz%C3%A9_Cornet" title="Alizé Cornet">Alizé Cornet</a> in the first two rounds, Williams faced Ukraine's <a href="/wiki/Elina_Svitolina" title="Elina Svitolina">Elina Svitolina</a> in the third round in what was a rematch of this year's French Open fourth round, but lost to the Ukrainian, bringing an end to her Olympics campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-239" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-239">[239]</a></sup> Days after the Olympics, Williams took a late wildcard for the <a href="/wiki/2016_Western_%26_Southern_Open" title="2016 Western &amp; Southern Open">Western &amp; Southern Open</a>, where she was the defending champion, but then decided to withdraw due to concerns from the same shoulder injury/inflammation from earlier in the summer.<sup id="cite_ref-240" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-240">[240]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The week of September 5, 2016, marked Williams's 186th consecutive week ranked No. 1, equalling Steffi Graf's record for longest run in WTA history. In the semifinals of the US Open, Williams lost to <a href="/wiki/Karol%C3%ADna_Pl%C3%AD%C5%A1kov%C3%A1" title="Karolína Plíšková">Karolína Plíšková</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-241" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-241">[241]</a></sup> Having won the US Open, Angelique Kerber became the No. 1, ending Williams's No. 1 streak. Williams also pulled out of the WTA Finals due to a shoulder injury.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2017:_Australian_Open_victory_and_pregnancy">2017: Australian Open victory and pregnancy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=13" title="Edit section: 2017: Australian Open victory and pregnancy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/2017_Serena_Williams_tennis_season" title="2017 Serena Williams tennis season">2017 Serena Williams tennis season</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams started her 2017 season by participating in the <a href="/wiki/WTA_Auckland_Open" title="WTA Auckland Open">WTA Auckland Open</a> for the first time in her career. She defeated <a href="/wiki/Pauline_Parmentier" title="Pauline Parmentier">Pauline Parmentier</a> to win her first match since the US Open. In the second round, she lost to <a href="/wiki/Madison_Brengle" title="Madison Brengle">Madison Brengle</a>. At the Australian Open, she beat former and present top 10 players <a href="/wiki/Belinda_Bencic" title="Belinda Bencic">Belinda Bencic</a>, Lucie Šafářová, <a href="/wiki/Johanna_Konta" title="Johanna Konta">Johanna Konta</a> among others to reach her 8th Australian Open final. On January 28, 2017, she won the Australian Open for an Open Era record seventh time, defeating her sister, Venus.<sup id="cite_ref-242" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-242">[242]</a></sup> It was her 23rd Grand Slam singles title, surpassing Steffi Graf's Open Era record of 22. It was the first time in the Open Era that two players aged 35 or older had competed in the final of a Grand Slam tournament. The win ensured her return to the No. 1 ranking.<sup id="cite_ref-243" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-243">[243]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-244" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-244">[244]</a></sup> Williams subsequently withdrew from the <a href="/wiki/2017_BNP_Paribas_Open" title="2017 BNP Paribas Open">Indian Wells</a> and <a href="/wiki/2017_Miami_Open" title="2017 Miami Open">Miami</a> Opens, citing a knee injury.<sup id="cite_ref-245" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-245">[245]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On April 19, 2017, Williams revealed that she was 20 weeks pregnant and would miss the remainder of the season.<sup id="cite_ref-246" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-246">[246]</a></sup> The timing of her announcement led to the conclusion that she would have been roughly eight to nine weeks pregnant when she won the Australian Open.<sup id="cite_ref-247" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-247">[247]</a></sup> In interviews, she maintained that she intended to return to tennis after her pregnancy,<sup id="cite_ref-voguesept17_248-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-voguesept17-248">[248]</a></sup> saying that she had an "outrageous plan" of competing in the 2018 Australian Open.<sup id="cite_ref-voguesept17_248-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-voguesept17-248">[248]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On September 1, 2017, Williams gave birth to a daughter named Alexis Olympia Ohanian Jr.<sup id="cite_ref-249" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-249">[249]</a></sup> She had a cesarean-section delivery due to a <a href="/wiki/Pulmonary_embolism" title="Pulmonary embolism">pulmonary embolism</a> during labor.<sup id="cite_ref-Rubenstein_250-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rubenstein-250">[250]</a></sup> She suffered another pulmonary embolism after giving birth, leaving her bedridden for six weeks and delaying her return to training.<sup id="cite_ref-vogue.com_251-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vogue.com-251">[251]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On December 30, 2017, Williams played her first match since giving birth, an exhibition match at the <a href="/wiki/World_Tennis_Championship" title="World Tennis Championship">World Tennis Championship</a> in <a href="/wiki/Abu_Dhabi" title="Abu Dhabi">Abu Dhabi</a>, losing to reigning French Open champion <a href="/wiki/Je%C4%BCena_Ostapenko" title="Jeļena Ostapenko">Jeļena Ostapenko</a>. </p> 
      <h3><span id="2018:_Return_to_tennis.2C_Wimbledon_and_US_Open_runner_up"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2018:_Return_to_tennis,_Wimbledon_and_US_Open_runner_up">2018: Return to tennis, Wimbledon and US Open runner up</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=14" title="Edit section: 2018: Return to tennis, Wimbledon and US Open runner up">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>On January 5, 2018, Williams withdrew from the upcoming Australian Open, citing a lack of sufficient preparation in the wake of her pregnancy.<sup id="cite_ref-252" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-252">[252]</a></sup> In February, after overcoming her pregnancy-induced health problems, she returned to the tennis court with her sister. The pair lost to Lesley Kerkhove and Demi Schuurs (Netherlands) in the Fed Cup's first round on February 11.<sup id="cite_ref-253" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-253">[253]</a></sup> Despite saying she was 100% ready to come back to tennis, Williams suffered back to back early exits at Indian Wells and Miami, losing in the third round at Indian Wells to her sister Venus and the first round at Miami to 2018 Indian Wells champion Naomi Osaka.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <div class="thumb tleft">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Williams_S._RG18_(17)_(41168711240).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Williams_S._RG18_%2817%29_%2841168711240%29.jpg/220px-Williams_S._RG18_%2817%29_%2841168711240%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="331" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Williams_S._RG18_%2817%29_%2841168711240%29.jpg/330px-Williams_S._RG18_%2817%29_%2841168711240%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Williams_S._RG18_%2817%29_%2841168711240%29.jpg/440px-Williams_S._RG18_%2817%29_%2841168711240%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="1947" data-file-height="2931"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Williams_S._RG18_(17)_(41168711240).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>
         <div style="text-align: center;">
          Williams at the 2018 French Open
         </div>
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams made her return to Grand Slam tennis at the <a href="/wiki/2018_French_Open" title="2018 French Open">2018 French Open</a>, playing singles as well as doubles with her sister Venus. In the first round, she defeated <a href="/wiki/Krist%C3%BDna_Pl%C3%AD%C5%A1kov%C3%A1" title="Kristýna Plíšková">Kristýna Plíšková</a> in two tight sets before defeating 17th seed <a href="/wiki/Ashleigh_Barty" title="Ashleigh Barty">Ashleigh Barty</a> in the second round. Then, she defeated 11th seed <a href="/wiki/Julia_G%C3%B6rges" title="Julia Görges">Julia Görges</a> to set up a fourth-round match against 28th seed <a href="/wiki/Maria_Sharapova" title="Maria Sharapova">Maria Sharapova</a>, whom she had beaten 18 consecutive times since 2004. Williams withdrew due to an injury to her <a href="/wiki/Pectoralis_major_muscle" class="mw-redirect" title="Pectoralis major muscle">pectoral</a> muscle sustained in a third-round match in doubles where she and Venus were defeated by <a href="/wiki/Andreja_Klepa%C4%8D" title="Andreja Klepač">Andreja Klepač</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mar%C3%ADa_Jos%C3%A9_Mart%C3%ADnez_S%C3%A1nchez" title="María José Martínez Sánchez">María José Martínez Sánchez</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-254" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-254">[254]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-255" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-255">[255]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In July, Williams entered the <a href="/wiki/The_Championships,_Wimbledon" title="The Championships, Wimbledon">Wimbledon Championships</a> and was controversially seeded #25. With a world ranking at the time of 181,<sup id="cite_ref-256" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-256">[256]</a></sup> many felt that the decision showed bias and favored Williams unduly.<sup id="cite_ref-surprise_257-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-surprise-257">[257]</a></sup> Others argued that the <a href="/wiki/All_England_Lawn_Tennis_and_Croquet_Club" title="All England Lawn Tennis and Croquet Club">All England Club</a>, who do not base their seedings on players' current world rankings – as other grand slam tournaments do<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>– had sensibly taken Williams' excellent historic record at the tournament into account. Williams herself said: "I was pleasantly surprised. I came in here expecting that maybe I wouldn't get a seed."<sup id="cite_ref-surprise_257-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-surprise-257">[257]</a></sup> Her seeding meant that <a href="/wiki/Dominika_Cibulkov%C3%A1" title="Dominika Cibulková">Dominika Cibulková</a> lost her place as a seeded player.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>By the second week of the tournament, for the first time in grand slam history, none of the top ten seeded female players had made it to the quarterfinals.<sup id="cite_ref-258" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-258">[258]</a></sup> On her own way to the quarterfinals, Williams had beaten <a href="/wiki/Arantxa_Rus" title="Arantxa Rus">Arantxa Rus</a> of Holland in round one, <a href="/wiki/Viktoriya_Tomova" title="Viktoriya Tomova">Viktoriya Tomova</a> of Bulgaria in round 2, <a href="/wiki/Kristina_Mladenovic" title="Kristina Mladenovic">Kristina Mladenovic</a> of France in round 3 and <a href="/wiki/Evgeniya_Rodina" title="Evgeniya Rodina">Evgeniya Rodina</a> of Russia in round 4.<sup id="cite_ref-259" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-259">[259]</a></sup> She had not yet lost a set in any of her matches to that point. Williams then beat Italian <a href="/wiki/Camila_Giorgi" title="Camila Giorgi">Camila Giorgi</a> in the quarterfinals after yielding one set, and became the lowest ranked player to ever reach the Wimbledon semifinals.<sup id="cite_ref-260" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-260">[260]</a></sup> She met 13th seed <a href="/wiki/Julia_G%C3%B6rges" title="Julia Görges">Julia Görges</a> of Germany in the semifinal and beat her comfortably in two sets to reach her tenth Wimbledon final, and her first since giving birth. She lost in the final in straight sets to <a href="/wiki/Angelique_Kerber" title="Angelique Kerber">Angelique Kerber</a> of Germany in a rematch of the 2016 Wimbledon final. </p>
      <p>Following her Wimbledon finals run, Williams entered the <a href="/wiki/2018_Silicon_Valley_Classic" title="2018 Silicon Valley Classic">2018 Silicon Valley Classic</a>, her first appearance in a US Open series tournament since 2015. She recorded her most lopsided loss in her career to <a href="/wiki/Johanna_Konta" title="Johanna Konta">Johanna Konta</a> in the first round, winning just a single game.<sup id="cite_ref-261" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-261">[261]</a></sup> Williams later revealed in an interview with <a href="/wiki/Time_(magazine)" title="Time (magazine)"><i>Time</i></a> that she checked <a href="/wiki/Instagram" title="Instagram">Instagram</a> ten minutes prior to the match starting, and found out that the man who had <a href="/wiki/Murder_of_Yetunde_Price" title="Murder of Yetunde Price">fatally shot</a> her half-sister, Yetunde, in 2003 was released on parole earlier in the year. She said in the interview, "I couldn't shake it out of my mind."<sup id="cite_ref-262" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-262">[262]</a></sup> She then withdrew from Toronto, citing personal reasons, which were later revealed to be <a href="/wiki/Post-natal_depression" class="mw-redirect" title="Post-natal depression">post-natal depression</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams' next tournament was the <a href="/wiki/2018_Western_%26_Southern_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2018 Western &amp; Southern Open – Women's Singles">Cincinnati Masters</a>. She beat <a href="/wiki/Daria_Gavrilova" title="Daria Gavrilova">Daria Gavrilova</a> of Australia in straight sets in the first round, but lost to <a href="/wiki/Petra_Kvitova" class="mw-redirect" title="Petra Kvitova">Petra Kvitova</a> in the second round in a three-set match that lasted over two hours.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> Her next tournament was the 2018 US Open in Flushing Meadows, New York, where she was seeded 17th, although ranked 26th in the WTA ranking at the time seeds were determined. She defeated <a href="/wiki/Magda_Linette" title="Magda Linette">Magda Linette</a> in the first round, <a href="/wiki/Carina_Witth%C3%B6ft" title="Carina Witthöft">Carina Witthöft</a> in the second round, her sister and 16th seed Venus in the third round, <a href="/wiki/Kaia_Kanepi" title="Kaia Kanepi">Kaia Kanepi</a> in the fourth round, and 8th seed <a href="/wiki/Karol%C3%ADna_Pl%C3%AD%C5%A1kov%C3%A1" title="Karolína Plíšková">Karolína Plíšková</a> in the quarterfinals. The match against Plíšková was a rematch of the 2016 US Open semifinal, which Plíšková had won. This was Williams' first win against a player in the top 10 (at the time of the match) since her return from pregnancy. Williams won her semifinal match against 19th seed <a href="/wiki/Anastasija_Sevastova" title="Anastasija Sevastova">Anastasija Sevastova</a> of Latvia, winning a spot in the <a href="/wiki/2018_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles_final" title="2018 US Open – Women's Singles final">women's singles final</a> against <a href="/wiki/Naomi_Osaka" title="Naomi Osaka">Naomi Osaka</a> of Japan which she lost in straight sets.
