Williams was warned for illegal coaching, penalized a point for breaking her racket, and then penalized a game for verbal abuse of the chair umpire. </p> 
      <h3><span id="2019:_Return_to_the_top_10.2C_injuries.2C_Wimbledon_and_US_Open_runner-up"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="2019:_Return_to_the_top_10,_injuries,_Wimbledon_and_US_Open_runner-up">2019: Return to the top 10, injuries, Wimbledon and US Open runner-up</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=15" title="Edit section: 2019: Return to the top 10, injuries, Wimbledon and US Open runner-up">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:262px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Murraywilliams_2019.jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Murraywilliams_2019.jpg/260px-Murraywilliams_2019.jpg" decoding="async" width="260" height="188" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Murraywilliams_2019.jpg/390px-Murraywilliams_2019.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/90/Murraywilliams_2019.jpg/520px-Murraywilliams_2019.jpg 2x" data-file-width="2815" data-file-height="2035"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Murraywilliams_2019.jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Williams and 
         <a href="/wiki/Andy_Murray" title="Andy Murray">Andy Murray</a> have joined up for the mixed doubles at Wimbledon 2019
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams started her 2019 season at the <a href="/wiki/2019_Australian_Open" title="2019 Australian Open">Australian Open</a>, having not made an appearance at the tournament since winning the 2017 edition. Seeded 16th, she defeated <a href="/wiki/Tatjana_Maria" title="Tatjana Maria">Tatjana Maria</a>, <a href="/wiki/Eugenie_Bouchard" title="Eugenie Bouchard">Eugenie Bouchard</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Dayana_Yastremska" title="Dayana Yastremska">Dayana Yastremska</a> in the first three rounds, before defeating top seed and world number one <a href="/wiki/Simona_Halep" title="Simona Halep">Simona Halep</a> in the fourth. In the quarterfinals, she met 7th seed <a href="/wiki/Karol%C3%ADna_Pl%C3%AD%C5%A1kov%C3%A1" title="Karolína Plíšková">Karolína Plíšková</a>. Plíšková won the first set and lead in the second, but Williams took control of the match, winning the second and rapidly taking a huge lead in the third. However, after Williams twisted her ankle while up match point, Plíšková won six consecutive games, saving four match points throughout the set to win the match. This was Williams' earliest defeat at the Australian Open since her fourth-round loss in <a href="/wiki/2014_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2014 Australian Open – Women's Singles">2014</a>, and broke a streak of fourteen consecutive match wins in Grand Slam quarterfinals (having last lost a Grand Slam quarterfinal at the <a href="/wiki/2013_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2013 Australian Open – Women's Singles">2013 Australian Open</a>). Despite this loss, her ranking climbed up to number 11.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams went on to defeat <a href="/wiki/Victoria_Azarenka" title="Victoria Azarenka">Victoria Azarenka</a> in the second round of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_Wells_Masters" title="Indian Wells Masters">Indian Wells Masters</a> in her 2019 campaign for a third Indian Wells crown. In the third round, viral illness caused her to retire against Spain's <a href="/wiki/Garbi%C3%B1e_Muguruza" title="Garbiñe Muguruza">Garbiñe Muguruza</a>. This was the second consecutive year she had exited at this stage. She then sustained a recurrence of a long-term knee injury which caused her to pull out of Miami and Rome after playing one match. She could not train properly until after the French Open, where she lost in the third round.<sup id="cite_ref-263" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-263">[263]</a></sup> At <a href="/wiki/2019_Wimbledon_Championships_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2019 Wimbledon Championships – Women's Singles">Wimbledon</a>, Williams reached a major final for the 13th consecutive year. She also became the oldest grand slam finalist in the open era.<sup id="cite_ref-264" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-264">[264]</a></sup> She lost the final to <a href="/wiki/Simona_Halep" title="Simona Halep">Simona Halep</a> in two straight sets in under an hour.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>At the <a href="/wiki/Canadian_Open_(tennis)" title="Canadian Open (tennis)">Canadian Open</a>, Williams defeated <a href="/wiki/Naomi_Osaka" title="Naomi Osaka">Naomi Osaka</a> in straight sets in the quarterfinals and Czech qualifier <a href="/wiki/Marie_Bouzkova" class="mw-redirect" title="Marie Bouzkova">Marie Bouzkova</a> in three sets in the semi finals. Against Canadian teenager <a href="/wiki/Bianca_Andreescu" title="Bianca Andreescu">Bianca Andreescu</a>, she retired in the first set after 19 minutes. She told the chair umpire of her decision to retire because of back spasms.<sup id="cite_ref-265" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-265">[265]</a></sup> Her back problems continued at the <a href="/wiki/Cincinnati_Masters" title="Cincinnati Masters">Cincinnati Open</a>, where she withdrew shortly before her first-round match, stating, "Unfortunately my back is still not right."<sup id="cite_ref-266" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-266">[266]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams was seeded eighth at the <a href="/wiki/2019_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2019 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a>. In the first round she met Maria Sharapova for the first time since the 2016 Australian Open, defeating her in straight sets, yielding just one game in each set. She defeated <a href="/wiki/Caty_McNally" title="Caty McNally">Caty McNally</a> in three sets in the second round, and <a href="/wiki/Karol%C3%ADna_Muchov%C3%A1" title="Karolína Muchová">Karolína Muchová</a> and <a href="/wiki/Petra_Marti%C4%87" title="Petra Martić">Petra Martić</a> in straight games in the third and fourth. In the quarterfinals she faced 18th seed <a href="/wiki/Wang_Qiang_(tennis)" title="Wang Qiang (tennis)">Wang Qiang</a>, who she overcame in just 45 minutes, yielding a single game. In the semifinals she defeated fifth seed Elina Svitolina, proceeding to the final where she faced 15th seed Bianca Andreescu for the second time in under a month. With Andreescu up a set and five games to one in the second set, Williams launched a spirited comeback to level the set at 5-games-all. However, Andreescu was able to hold serve and break Williams to win the title in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-267" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-267">[267]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Rivalries">Rivalries</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=16" title="Edit section: Rivalries">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Serena_vs._Venus">Serena vs. Venus</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=17" title="Edit section: Serena vs. Venus">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Williams_sisters_rivalry" title="Williams sisters rivalry">Williams sisters rivalry</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams has played older sister <a href="/wiki/Venus_Williams" title="Venus Williams">Venus</a> in 30 professional matches since 1998.<sup id="cite_ref-headtohead_55-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-headtohead-55">[55]</a></sup> Overall, Serena is 18–12 against her sister.<sup id="cite_ref-headtohead_55-5" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-headtohead-55">[55]</a></sup> Serena has played Venus 15 times in Grand Slam singles and 13 times in other tournaments (including 11 finals).<sup id="cite_ref-268" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-268">[268]</a></sup> They have met in nine Grand Slam tournament finals, with Serena winning seven times.<sup id="cite_ref-headtohead_55-6" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-headtohead-55">[55]</a></sup> Beginning with the <a href="/wiki/2002_French_Open" title="2002 French Open">2002 French Open</a>, they played each other in four consecutive Grand Slam finals, which was the first time in the Open Era that the same two players had contested four consecutive finals in Grand Slam singles.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Williams_vs._Hingis">Williams vs. Hingis</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=18" title="Edit section: Williams vs. Hingis">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Hingis%E2%80%93S._Williams_rivalry" title="Hingis–S. Williams rivalry">Hingis–S. Williams rivalry</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams leads the series 7–6.<sup id="cite_ref-269" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-269">[269]</a></sup> One of Williams's first rivalries was with Martina Hingis, who turned pro less than one year before her (Hingis in October 1994, Williams in 1995). They first played each other at the 1998 Miami Open where Hingis won in three sets. All but one of their matches was played on a hard court with the exception being a contest on clay in Rome 1999, which Hingis won in straight sets. Their last match took place at the 2002 Miami Open with Williams winning in a loss of just four games.<sup id="cite_ref-270" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-270">[270]</a></sup> Hingis was forced to briefly retire citing ankle injuries.<sup id="cite_ref-271" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-271">[271]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Williams_vs._Capriati">Williams vs. Capriati</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=19" title="Edit section: Williams vs. Capriati">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Williams leads the series 10–7.<sup id="cite_ref-wtatennis.com_272-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtatennis.com-272">[272]</a></sup> Once considered one of the best rivalries in women's tennis,<sup id="cite_ref-273" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-273">[273]</a></sup> the competition between Williams and Capriati was stiff with 12 out of their 17 meetings going to three sets. The rivalry, starting in 1999, began one sided with Capriati winning four of their first five matches. Williams would then go on to win the next eight.<sup id="cite_ref-wtatennis.com_272-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-wtatennis.com-272">[272]</a></sup> Williams and Capriati played with similar styles, both known for using their power and athleticism to gain quick advantages in points.<sup id="cite_ref-274" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-274">[274]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-275" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-275">[275]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Williams_vs._Henin">Williams vs. Henin</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=20" title="Edit section: Williams vs. Henin">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Henin%E2%80%93S._Williams_rivalry" title="Henin–S. Williams rivalry">Henin–S. Williams rivalry</a>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams leads the series 8–6. Henin and Williams met 14 times, five of which were in tournament finals. In grand slams they have faced each other seven times with Henin leading 4–3.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_276-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-276">[276]</a></sup> Opposite personalities and styles of play are often cited as what made their rivalry entertaining.<sup id="cite_ref-277" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-277">[277]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-278" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-278">[278]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In the semifinals of the 2003 French Open, when at 4–2, 30–0 on Williams's serve in the third set, Henin raised her hand to indicate she was not ready to receive; Williams then put her serve into the net. The umpire did not see Henin raise her hand, and thus did not allow Williams a first serve. Williams lost the game and would go on to lose the match. Their last match took place in the final of the 2010 Australian Open where Williams won in three sets, earning her 12th Grand Slam title.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceA_276-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceA-276">[276]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Williams_vs._Azarenka">Williams vs. Azarenka</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=21" title="Edit section: Williams vs. Azarenka">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <table class="box-BLP_unsourced_section plainlinks metadata ambox ambox-content ambox-BLP_unsourced" role="presentation">
       <tbody>
        <tr>
         <td class="mbox-image">
          <div style="width:52px">
           <img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/40px-Ambox_important.svg.png" decoding="async" width="40" height="40" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/60px-Ambox_important.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/b/b4/Ambox_important.svg/80px-Ambox_important.svg.png 2x" data-file-width="40" data-file-height="40">
          </div></td>
         <td class="mbox-text">
          <div class="mbox-text-span">
           This section of a 
           <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Biographies_of_living_persons" title="Wikipedia:Biographies of living persons">biography of a living person</a> 
           <b>does not <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citing_sources" title="Wikipedia:Citing sources">include</a> any <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability">references or sources</a></b>.
           <span class="hide-when-compact"> Please help by adding <a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Reliable_sources" title="Wikipedia:Reliable sources">reliable sources</a>. Contentious material about living people that is unsourced or poorly sourced <b>must be removed immediately</b>.<br><small><span class="plainlinks"><i>Find sources:</i>&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?as_eq=wikipedia&amp;q=%22Serena+Williams%22">"Serena Williams"</a>&nbsp;–&nbsp;<a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbm=nws&amp;q=%22Serena+Williams%22+-wikipedia">news</a>&nbsp;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?&amp;q=%22Serena+Williams%22+site:news.google.com/newspapers&amp;source=newspapers">newspapers</a>&nbsp;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//www.google.com/search?tbs=bks:1&amp;q=%22Serena+Williams%22+-wikipedia">books</a>&nbsp;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="//scholar.google.com/scholar?q=%22Serena+Williams%22">scholar</a>&nbsp;<b>·</b> <a rel="nofollow" class="external text" href="https://www.jstor.org/action/doBasicSearch?Query=%22Serena+Williams%22&amp;acc=on&amp;wc=on">JSTOR</a></span></small></span> 
           <small class="date-container"><i>(<span class="date">July 2019</span>)</i></small>
           <small class="hide-when-compact"><i> (<a href="/wiki/Help:Maintenance_template_removal" title="Help:Maintenance template removal">Learn how and when to remove this template message</a>)</i></small>
          </div></td>
        </tr>
       </tbody>
      </table> 
      <p>Williams leads the series 18–4. The rivalry began at the 2008 Australian Open. Serena holds a 10–0 record in Grand Slams. Victoria Azarenka is the only person to ever win four WTA tour level finals against Serena. While their rivalry is heavily favored towards Serena, their matches are known for their fierce competitiveness.<sup id="cite_ref-279" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-279">[279]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Match_controversies">Match controversies</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=22" title="Edit section: Match controversies">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Accusations_of_match_fixing">Accusations of match fixing</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=23" title="Edit section: Accusations of match fixing">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>When both of the Williams sisters entered the top ten and started meeting in tournaments, rumors of <a href="/wiki/Match_fixing" title="Match fixing">match fixing</a> started to circulate. <a href="/wiki/John_McEnroe" title="John McEnroe">John McEnroe</a>, while commenting on the 2000 Wimbledon semifinal between the two sisters, said that "Serena may not be allowed to win. Richard [Williams] may have something to say about this."<sup id="cite_ref-280" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-280">[280]</a></sup> After losing to Venus at the Indian Wells quarterfinals in 2001, <a href="/wiki/Elena_Dementieva" title="Elena Dementieva">Elena Dementieva</a> asserted during a post-match interview that Richard Williams decided the results of matches between the two sisters.<sup id="cite_ref-281" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-281">[281]</a></sup> Shortly after that, Venus Williams pulled out of her Indian Wells semifinal match against Serena Williams at the last minute, citing tendinitis; this occurrence garnered much speculation in the press, and some fans demanded their money back.<sup id="cite_ref-etank_282-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-etank-282">[282]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-swn_283-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-swn-283">[283]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-telfix_284-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-telfix-284">[284]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Indian_Wells_boycott">Indian Wells boycott</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=24" title="Edit section: Indian Wells boycott">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>At the 2001 Ericsson Open the following week, Richard Williams stated that racist comments were made to him in the stands,<sup id="cite_ref-285" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-285">[285]</a></sup> and the tournament director refused to offer Williams an apology for how she was treated. As a result, neither sister played the tournament even though it had become a mandatory stop on the WTA tour since 2009. In 2015, Williams decided to end her 14-year boycott and played.<sup id="cite_ref-286" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-286">[286]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2004_US_Open">2004 US Open</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=25" title="Edit section: 2004 US Open">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>In her <a href="/wiki/2004_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2004 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> quarterfinal match against <a href="/wiki/Jennifer_Capriati" title="Jennifer Capriati">Jennifer Capriati</a>, an incorrect overrule was made by chair umpire <a href="/wiki/Mariana_Alves" class="mw-redirect" title="Mariana Alves">Mariana Alves</a>; the video review showed that Williams's shot landed in bounds. In the same match, new technology being tested made incorrect line calls late in the third set. Williams argued with the chair over a couple of calls during the match, but was not successful. Capriati won the match, with Serena herself acknowledging that this was primarily due to her 57 unforced errors; nevertheless, she accused Alves of temporary insanity<sup id="cite_ref-287" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-287">[287]</a></sup> and said that she "felt cheated."<sup id="cite_ref-288" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-288">[288]</a></sup> In a post-match interview Capriati sharply observed that bad calls had gone against her in the past as well. Alves did not officiate for the remainder of the tournament; this was not punitive, as commonly thought, as she was not scheduled to officiate.<sup id="cite_ref-289" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-289">[289]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>The controversy renewed calls for, and was widely given credit for, the adoption of technology such as the <a href="/wiki/MacCAM" title="MacCAM">MacCAM</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hawk-Eye" title="Hawk-Eye">Hawk-Eye</a> systems.<sup id="cite_ref-290" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-290">[290]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2009_US_Open">2009 US Open</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=26" title="Edit section: 2009 US Open">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>In the <a href="/wiki/2009_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2009 US Open (tennis)">US Open</a> semifinal round against <a href="/wiki/Kim_Clijsters" title="Kim Clijsters">Kim Clijsters</a>, Williams slammed her racket on the court after losing the first set. She was given a warning, with a potential second violation carrying a one-point penalty. While trailing 4–6, 5–6, 15–30, Williams's second serve was called a <a href="/wiki/Foot_fault" class="mw-redirect" title="Foot fault">foot fault</a>, resulting in two match points for Clijsters. Williams gestured with her racket to the lineswoman who had made the call and yelled at her, with profanities and a threat to shove a tennis ball down the lineswoman's throat.<sup id="cite_ref-291" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-291">[291]</a></sup> During the subsequent on-court conference between the chair umpire, the lineswoman, US Open officials, and Williams, a television microphone picked up Williams saying to the lineswoman, "I didn't say I would kill you! Are you serious?"<sup id="cite_ref-292" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-292">[292]</a></sup> The incident resulted in Williams being penalized a point for unsportsmanlike conduct‍—‌necessitated by the earlier warning for racket abuse‍—‌meaning Clijsters won the match 6–4, 7–5. The following day, Williams was issued the maximum permissible on-site fine of $10,000 (plus $500 for racket abuse). After further investigation, the Grand Slam Committee in November 2009 fined her $175,000 in place of suspending her from the 2010 US Open or other Grand Slam events.<sup id="cite_ref-Hefty_Fine_NY_Times_293-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hefty_Fine_NY_Times-293">[293]</a></sup> They also placed her on a two-year probation which provided that if Williams committed another offense at a Grand Slam event in the next two years, she would be suspended from participating in the following US Open. If, however, she committed no offenses within the next two years, her fine would be reduced to $82,500.<sup id="cite_ref-Hefty_Fine_NY_Times_293-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hefty_Fine_NY_Times-293">[293]</a></sup> Williams initially refused to apologize for her outburst, both in her post-match press conference<sup id="cite_ref-294" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-294">[294]</a></sup> and in an official statement released the following day.<sup id="cite_ref-lat2009_124-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-lat2009-124">[124]</a></sup> She eventually did apologize, stating "I just really wanted to apologize sincerely because I'm a very prideful person, and I'm a very intense person and a very emotional person", and "I wanted to offer my sincere apologies to anyone that I may have offended." She said she was humbled by the experience.<sup id="cite_ref-295" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-295">[295]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2011_US_Open">2011 US Open</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=27" title="Edit section: 2011 US Open">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>In the final of the <a href="/wiki/2011_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2011 US Open (tennis)">2011 US Open</a> against <a href="/wiki/Samantha_Stosur" title="Samantha Stosur">Samantha Stosur</a>, Williams shouted "Come on!" as the Australian attempted to return a <a href="/wiki/Forehand" title="Forehand">forehand</a> Williams believed to be a winner. The chair umpire <a href="/wiki/Eva_Asderaki" class="mw-redirect" title="Eva Asderaki">Eva Asderaki</a> awarded the point to Stosur based on the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Tennis_Association" title="United States Tennis Association">USTA</a>'s deliberate hindrance rule, which states, "If a player commits any act which hinders his opponent in making a stroke, then, if this is deliberate, he shall lose the point or if involuntary, the point shall be replayed."<sup id="cite_ref-296" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-296">[296]</a></sup> As the point was 30–40 on Williams's serve, the penalty gave the break of serve to Stosur. Williams became angry with the chair umpire and made several gestures and unflattering comments toward her during the next changeover, including telling Asderaki that if the umpire ever saw Serena coming toward her, she should "look the other way".<sup id="cite_ref-297" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-297">[297]</a></sup> Williams initially gained momentum in the set following the penalty, breaking back in the next game, but eventually flagged and lost the match, 2–6, 3–6. At the end of the match, she declined to offer the customary handshake to Asderaki.<sup id="cite_ref-298" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-298">[298]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-299" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-299">[299]</a></sup> Williams mentioned the incident in her post-match speech as the tournament runner-up, asserting, "I hit a winner, but I guess it didn't count", but added, "It wouldn't have mattered in the end. Sam played well."<sup id="cite_ref-300" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-300">[300]</a></sup> A writer for <a href="/wiki/ESPN" title="ESPN">ESPN</a> suggested that Williams could avoid being found to have violated the terms of the "probation" on which she was placed following her 2009 outburst, as she did not appear to have used <a href="/wiki/Profanity" title="Profanity">profanity</a> in addressing Asderaki during the match.<sup id="cite_ref-301" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-301">[301]</a></sup> In the end, Williams was fined $2,000 and was not barred from competing in the 2012 US Open because "Williams's conduct, while verbally abusive, [did] not rise to the level of a major offence under the Grand Slam code of conduct."<sup id="cite_ref-302" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-302">[302]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="2018_US_Open">2018 US Open</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=28" title="Edit section: 2018 US Open">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Williams' 2018 US Open ended in controversy, with Williams falling to <a href="/wiki/Naomi_Osaka" title="Naomi Osaka">Naomi Osaka</a> in straight sets following a game penalty in the second set of the <a href="/wiki/2018_US_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles_final" title="2018 US Open – Women's Singles final">final</a>. During that second set, she was given a code violation because her coach, <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Mouratoglou" title="Patrick Mouratoglou">Patrick Mouratoglou</a>, gave her coaching hand signals. Williams was upset by the violation, claiming that her coach was simply giving her a thumbs up, and demanded an apology from chair umpire <a href="/wiki/Carlos_Ramos_(umpire)" title="Carlos Ramos (umpire)">Carlos Ramos</a>. Mouratoglou later admitted that he had been coaching.<sup id="cite_ref-303" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-303">[303]</a></sup> She received a second violation for smashing her racket on the court, which resulted in a point penalty. After her third code violation for verbal abuse against the umpire, Williams was assessed a game penalty.<sup id="cite_ref-304" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-304">[304]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-305" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-305">[305]</a></sup> Williams said that she believed she had been treated unfairly by the umpire because she is a woman.<sup id="cite_ref-306" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-306">[306]</a></sup> Williams was fined a total of $17,000, that included $4,000 for a coaching violation, $3,000 for racket abuse and $10,000 for verbal abuse towards the umpire.<sup id="cite_ref-307" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-307">[307]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Discrimination">Discrimination</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=29" title="Edit section: Discrimination">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <p>Williams has been the focus of criticism and commentary, some of which the Williams family, news media, and scholars have stated was discriminatory against her due to her race and gender. </p>
      <p>In the beginning years of Williams’ professional career, cultural beads donned by the Williams sisters were the focus of discussion by commentators such as Chris Evert and John McEnroe, with Mary Carillo characterizing their hair as “noisy and disruptive."<sup id="cite_ref-:02_308-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-308">[308]</a></sup> Scholars Nancy Spencer and Jamie Schultz have stated that commentary that dismissed the Williams' cultural hairstyles served to <a href="/wiki/Other_(philosophy)" title="Other (philosophy)">Other</a> the sisters, particularly in the context of a white dominated sport where their appearance and specifically their physicality is a popular topic for discussion.<sup id="cite_ref-:02_308-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-308">[308]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-309" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-309">[309]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2000 the Williams sisters faced each other in a Grand Slam Tournament in a semifinal match at Wimbledon, the first time the sisters had faced each other in this setting. After Venus won in straight sets, questions arose as to whether or not Richard Williams fixed the match. These questions increased in 2001 when Venus withdrew from her scheduled semifinal match against her sister at Indian Wells. Two days later, in the finals of Indian Wells, Williams was booed throughout the match.<sup id="cite_ref-:02_308-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-308">[308]</a></sup> When Venus and Richard Williams entered the stadium to support Williams in the finals, Richard proclaimed that a dozen fans in the stands yelled racial slurs at him and his daughter, with one fan yelling “skin him alive."<sup id="cite_ref-:02_308-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:02-308">[308]</a></sup> Following this match, the Williams sisters boycotted Indian Wells until Williams returned in 2015 and Venus in 2016.<sup id="cite_ref-310" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-310">[310]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Following the match controversy at the 2018 US Open final between Williams and Naomi Osaka, a cartoon was released by the Herald Sun depicting Williams having a tantrum and breaking her racket while the umpire asks her opponent to “just let her win.”<sup id="cite_ref-311" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-311">[311]</a></sup> This cartoon was met with much criticism for being racist and sexist. Complaints centered around the portrayal of Williams as the angry black women with exaggerated large lips, a broad flat nose, and positioned in an ape like pose and of Williams’ opponent, Osaka, who is half Japanese half Haitian, being portrayed as white with blonde hair.<sup id="cite_ref-312" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-312">[312]</a></sup> Williams’ husband, Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian, called the cartoon sexist and misogynistic.<sup id="cite_ref-313" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-313">[313]</a></sup> Famous celebrities, including J.K. Rowling, came to Williams’ defence with similar views while the editor of the Herald Sun argued the cartoon was “unfairly” criticized on social media.<sup id="cite_ref-314" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-314">[314]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-:12_315-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12-315">[315]</a></sup> The cartoonist defended his work as his contribution to “stop family from being abused," a reference to Williams defending herself as a wife and mother in her dispute with the umpire.<sup id="cite_ref-:12_315-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12-315">[315]</a></sup> The cartoonist says his satire was never about race or gender, but was about putting a spotlight on bad behaviour by sporting superstars.<sup id="cite_ref-:12_315-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:12-315">[315]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In September 2019, Radu Banciu compared Williams to a zoo monkey live on Romanian TV. According to a press release by the National Council for Combating Discrimination in Bucharest translated by the Business Insider, Banciu proclaimed, among other comments, that “Serena Williams looks exactly like one of those monkeys at the zoo with the red asses.”<sup id="cite_ref-:22_316-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:22-316">[316]</a></sup> Banciu was fined approximately $1,875 for his comments.<sup id="cite_ref-:22_316-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:22-316">[316]</a></sup> Other than the fine, no punitive action was taken against Banciu regarding his job.<sup id="cite_ref-:22_316-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-:22-316">[316]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Legacy">Legacy</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=30" title="Edit section: Legacy">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <p>Williams is hailed by many coaches, players and sportscasters to be one of the best female tennis players of the Open Era.<sup id="cite_ref-317" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-317">[317]</a></sup> In 2018, a Tennis.com panel selected Serena as the greatest female tennis player in the Open Era.<sup id="cite_ref-318" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-318">[318]</a></sup> Her numerous victories on court have largely been a positive influence on young girls and boys who see Williams as a role model and an ambassador of tennis.<sup id="cite_ref-319" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-319">[319]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-320" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-320">[320]</a></sup> However, there is a sizable percentage of people who disagree.<sup id="cite_ref-321" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-321">[321]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-322" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-322">[322]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-323" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-323">[323]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-324" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-324">[324]</a></sup> Some commentators, players and sports writers regard Williams as the greatest female tennis player of all time.<sup id="cite_ref-339" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-339">[a]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-340" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-340">[339]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-341" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-341">[340]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>For their first match of March 2019, the women of the <a href="/wiki/United_States_women%27s_national_soccer_team" title="United States women's national soccer team">United States women's national soccer team</a> each wore a jersey with the name of a woman they were honoring on the back; <a href="/wiki/Crystal_Dunn" title="Crystal Dunn">Crystal Dunn</a> chose the name of Serena Williams.<sup id="cite_ref-342" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-342">[341]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=31" title="Edit section: Personal life">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div class="thumb tright">
       <div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;">
        <a href="/wiki/File:Web_Summit_2018_-_Centre_Stage,_Day_1_-November_6_SD5_6360_(44835575425).jpg" class="image"><img alt="" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Web_Summit_2018_-_Centre_Stage%2C_Day_1_-November_6_SD5_6360_%2844835575425%29.jpg/220px-Web_Summit_2018_-_Centre_Stage%2C_Day_1_-November_6_SD5_6360_%2844835575425%29.jpg" decoding="async" width="220" height="147" class="thumbimage" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Web_Summit_2018_-_Centre_Stage%2C_Day_1_-November_6_SD5_6360_%2844835575425%29.jpg/330px-Web_Summit_2018_-_Centre_Stage%2C_Day_1_-November_6_SD5_6360_%2844835575425%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Web_Summit_2018_-_Centre_Stage%2C_Day_1_-November_6_SD5_6360_%2844835575425%29.jpg/440px-Web_Summit_2018_-_Centre_Stage%2C_Day_1_-November_6_SD5_6360_%2844835575425%29.jpg 2x" data-file-width="5568" data-file-height="3712"></a> 
        <div class="thumbcaption">
         <div class="magnify">
          <a href="/wiki/File:Web_Summit_2018_-_Centre_Stage,_Day_1_-November_6_SD5_6360_(44835575425).jpg" class="internal" title="Enlarge"></a>
         </div>Serena Williams' husband 
         <a href="/wiki/Alexis_Ohanian" title="Alexis Ohanian">Alexis Ohanian</a> in 2018
        </div>
       </div>
      </div> 
      <p>Williams is married to <a href="/wiki/Reddit" title="Reddit">Reddit</a> co-founder <a href="/wiki/Alexis_Ohanian" title="Alexis Ohanian">Alexis Ohanian</a>. They were married on November 16, 2017, in <a href="/wiki/New_Orleans" title="New Orleans">New Orleans</a>. Guests at the wedding included <a href="/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyoncé">Beyoncé</a>, <a href="/wiki/Anna_Wintour" title="Anna Wintour">Anna Wintour</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kelly_Rowland" title="Kelly Rowland">Kelly Rowland</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kim_Kardashian_West" class="mw-redirect" title="Kim Kardashian West">Kim Kardashian West</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-343" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-343">[342]</a></sup> She planned to move to San Francisco with Ohanian after the wedding.<sup id="cite_ref-voguesept17_248-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-voguesept17-248">[248]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>On April 19, 2017, Williams posted a sideways picture of herself on <a href="/wiki/Snapchat" title="Snapchat">Snapchat</a> focused on her midsection. It had the caption, "20 weeks", sparking speculation that Williams was pregnant.<sup id="cite_ref-344" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-344">[343]</a></sup> Later that evening, her spokesperson confirmed that the couple was expecting.<sup id="cite_ref-345" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-345">[344]</a></sup> The fact that she was 20 weeks pregnant when announcing her pregnancy meant that she was 8 weeks pregnant when she won the Australian Open in January.<sup id="cite_ref-346" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-346">[345]</a></sup> Serena later confirmed that posting the photo on Snapchat was an accident and that she had intended to save the photo for her records.<sup id="cite_ref-347" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-347">[346]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In September 2017, Williams gave birth to a daughter.<sup id="cite_ref-uwlupohautman_348-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-uwlupohautman-348">[347]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-349" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-349">[348]</a></sup> Williams had a cesarean-section delivery due to complications (specifically, a blood clot in her lungs, referred to as a <a href="/wiki/Pulmonary_embolism" title="Pulmonary embolism">pulmonary embolism</a>) during the labor of her daughter and, at first, was devastated about it.<sup id="cite_ref-Rubenstein_250-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Rubenstein-250">[250]</a></sup> She suffered another pulmonary embolism after giving birth, leaving her bedridden for six weeks and delaying her return to training.<sup id="cite_ref-vogue.com_251-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-vogue.com-251">[251]</a></sup> In August 2018, Serena announced she was suffering from <a href="/wiki/Postpartum_depression" title="Postpartum depression">postpartum depression</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-350" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-350">[349]</a></sup> Williams gave her daughter a doll, <a href="/wiki/Qai_Qai" title="Qai Qai">Qai Qai</a> that has become famous on social media.<sup id="cite_ref-351" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-351">[350]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams was raised a <a href="/wiki/Jehovah%27s_Witness" class="mw-redirect" title="Jehovah's Witness">Jehovah's Witness</a>, but says she has "never really practiced it."<sup id="cite_ref-voguesept17_248-3" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-voguesept17-248">[248]</a></sup> She often thanks <a href="/wiki/Jehovah" title="Jehovah">Jehovah</a> after winning matches.<sup id="cite_ref-352" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-352">[351]</a></sup> Williams confirmed that she follows some practices: "Olympia doesn't celebrate birthdays. We're Jehovah's Witnesses, so we don't do that."<sup id="cite_ref-353" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-353">[352]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Off-court_activities">Off-court activities</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=32" title="Edit section: Off-court activities">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Equipment_and_endorsements">Equipment and endorsements</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=33" title="Edit section: Equipment and endorsements">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>In the early 2000s, Williams wore Puma apparel and footwear on court.<sup id="cite_ref-354" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-354">[353]</a></sup> She used the <a href="/wiki/Wilson_Sporting_Goods" title="Wilson Sporting Goods">Wilson</a> Hammer 6.4 Stretch Power Holes racket.<sup id="cite_ref-355" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-355">[354]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams also has endorsement deals with <a href="/wiki/Gatorade" title="Gatorade">Gatorade</a>, <a href="/wiki/Delta_Air_Lines" title="Delta Air Lines">Delta Air Lines</a>, <a href="/wiki/Audemars_Piguet" title="Audemars Piguet">Audemars Piguet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Aston_Martin" title="Aston Martin">Aston Martin</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pepsi" title="Pepsi">Pepsi</a>, <a href="/wiki/Beats_by_Dre" class="mw-redirect" title="Beats by Dre">Beats by Dre</a> headphones, Mission Athletecare, <a href="/wiki/Berlei" title="Berlei">Berlei</a> bras, <a href="/wiki/OPI_Products" title="OPI Products">OPI Products</a>, OnePiece, <a href="/wiki/IBM" title="IBM">IBM</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mini" title="Mini">Mini</a>, <a href="/wiki/Intel" title="Intel">Intel</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tempur" class="mw-redirect" title="Tempur">Tempur</a> and <a href="/wiki/Chase_Bank" title="Chase Bank">Chase Bank</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>Williams is the current<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Chronological_items" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers"><span title="The time period mentioned near this tag is ambiguous. (July 2019)">when?</span></a></i>]</sup> CSO (Chief Sporting Officer) for British luxury automobile manufacturer <a href="/wiki/Aston_Martin" title="Aston Martin">Aston Martin</a>. She accepted the contract in June 2015. Williams then posted her first experience on social media service <a href="/wiki/Twitter" title="Twitter">Twitter</a>, and said: "I'm loving my first day on the job as Chief Sporting Officer and Director of Fun!", stating her optimism on the job as the CSO.<sup id="cite_ref-356" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-356">[355]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-357" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-357">[356]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams is also on the Board of Directors at <a href="/wiki/SurveyMonkey" title="SurveyMonkey">SurveyMonkey</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-358" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-358">[357]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Fashion">Fashion</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=34" title="Edit section: Fashion">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Williams has been noted for her unusual and colorful outfits on court. In 2002, there was much talk when she wore a black lycra <a href="/wiki/Catsuit" title="Catsuit">catsuit</a> at the US Open.<sup id="cite_ref-359" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-359">[358]</a></sup> At the 2004 US Open, Williams wore denim skirts and knee-high boots—tournament officials did not allow her to wear the boots during matches.<sup id="cite_ref-360" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-360">[359]</a></sup> At the 2008 Wimbledon, the white <a href="/wiki/Trench_coat" title="Trench coat">trench coat</a> she wore during warm-up for her opening match was the subject of much discussion since it was worn despite sunny weather.<sup id="cite_ref-361" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-361">[360]</a></sup> Some social scientists have argued that the most negative reactions to Williams' on-court fashion statements, especially in newspaper coverage of the Australian Open and Wimbledon, combines with writers' fixation upon her muscular body to distract from her on-court accomplishments and fit this commentary within centuries-old narratives of the "pornographic eroticism" and "sexual grotesquerie" of African and African-American women.<sup id="cite_ref-362" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-362">[361]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams formerly had a special line with <a href="/wiki/Puma_AG" class="mw-redirect" title="Puma AG">Puma</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-363" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-363">[362]</a></sup> In April 2004, she signed a deal worth US$40<span class="nowrap">&nbsp;</span>million for a line with <a href="/wiki/Nike,_Inc." title="Nike, Inc.">Nike</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-364" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-364">[363]</a></sup> Since 2004, she has also run her own line of designer apparel, "Aneres"—her first name spelled backward. In 2009, she launched a signature collection of handbags and jewelry.<sup id="cite_ref-365" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-365">[364]</a></sup> The collection, Signature Statement, is sold mainly on the <a href="/wiki/Home_Shopping_Network" title="Home Shopping Network">Home Shopping Network</a> (HSN).<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In early 2010, Williams became a certified <a href="/wiki/Manicure#Nail_care" title="Manicure">nail technician</a> in preparation for her upcoming nail collection with a company called HairTech.<sup id="cite_ref-366" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-366">[365]</a></sup> In 2015, she became the first black female athlete to have a picture by herself on the cover of <i>Vogue</i>, which she did for the April 2015 issue.<sup id="cite_ref-367" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-367">[366]</a></sup> In 2015, she also presented her HSN Signature Statement collection for the second time at the New York Fashion Week Show‍—‌a clothing line exclusively made for the retailer HSN.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>In May 2018 she wore a skin-tight catsuit at the <a href="/wiki/2018_French_Open" title="2018 French Open">2018 French Open</a> that was likened to a superhero outfit and helped promote her new clothing line, <i>Serena</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-Racked2018_368-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Racked2018-368">[367]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-Vox2018_369-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Vox2018-369">[368]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-ESPN2018_370-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ESPN2018-370">[369]</a></sup> The outfit was subsequently banned by the <a href="/wiki/French_Tennis_Federation" title="French Tennis Federation">French Tennis Federation</a> president Bernard Giudicelli, with the explanation: "It will no longer be accepted. One must respect the game and the place." Williams then wore a black <a href="/wiki/Tutu_(clothing)" title="Tutu (clothing)">tutu</a> to her first match at the <a href="/wiki/2018_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2018 US Open (tennis)">2018 US Open</a> on August 27, 2018 against <a href="/wiki/Magda_Linette" title="Magda Linette">Magda Linette</a> which she dominated in straight sets.<sup id="cite_ref-Time2018_371-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Time2018-371">[370]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-SBNation2018_372-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SBNation2018-372">[371]</a></sup> In February 2019, Serena Williams was appointed to the board of directors of online fashion marketplace <a href="/wiki/Poshmark" title="Poshmark">Poshmark</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-373" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-373">[372]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Activism">Activism</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=35" title="Edit section: Activism">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Williams has become more involved in social change as her career has progressed, primarily using social media as a medium of expressing her views. In 2016 she posted her support of <a href="/wiki/Black_Lives_Matter" title="Black Lives Matter">Black Lives Matter</a> on her <a href="/wiki/Facebook" title="Facebook">Facebook</a> page, voicing her concern about her young nephew being in danger from police officers due to his skin color.<sup id="cite_ref-374" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-374">[373]</a></sup> During American tennis player <a href="/wiki/Tennys_Sandgren" title="Tennys Sandgren">Tennys Sandgren</a>'s breakthrough run to the quarterfinals of the 2018 Australian Open, it was revealed that he tweeted insensitive words about the <a href="/wiki/LGBT" title="LGBT">LGBT</a> community, followed members of the <a href="/wiki/Alt-right" title="Alt-right">alt-right</a>, and referred to an article describing Williams's on-court behavior as "disgusting". Williams responded by tweeting her displeasure, saying, "@TennysSandgren I don't need or want one. But there is a entire group of people that deserves an apology. I can't look at my daughter and tell her I sat back and was quiet. No! She will know how to stand up for herself and others – through my example." Additionally, she attached an image that read, "Maturity is being able to apologize and admit when you're wrong because you know that your mistakes don't define you".<sup id="cite_ref-375" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-375">[374]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams has received several awards for her activism, particularly for her activism directed towards Black communities. She was listed among the 35 "most remarkable and beautiful black women" in the world by Essence magazine.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_376-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-376">[375]</a></sup> The NAACP has honored Williams with the President's Award at the annual NAACP Image Awards.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup><sup id="cite_ref-377" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-377">[376]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Entertainment">Entertainment</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=36" title="Edit section: Entertainment">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>Williams has appeared on television and also provided voice work on animated shows: in a 2001 episode of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Simpsons" title="The Simpsons">The Simpsons</a></i> Serena joined the animation along with sister Venus, <a href="/wiki/Pete_Sampras" title="Pete Sampras">Pete Sampras</a> and <a href="/wiki/Andre_Agassi" title="Andre Agassi">Andre Agassi</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-378">[377]</a></sup> She has also provided guest voice work in a 2005 episode of Playhouse Disney's animated kids show <i><a href="/wiki/Higglytown_Heroes" title="Higglytown Heroes">Higglytown Heroes</a></i> and a 2007 episode of the <a href="/wiki/Nickelodeon" title="Nickelodeon">Nickelodeon</a> cartoon <i><a href="/wiki/Avatar:_The_Last_Airbender" title="Avatar: The Last Airbender">Avatar: The Last Airbender</a></i>,<sup id="cite_ref-379" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-379">[378]</a></sup> which she has described as her "favorite show".<sup id="cite_ref-380" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-380">[379]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams has posed for the 2003 and 2004 editions of the <i>Sports Illustrated Swimsuit Issue</i>.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-381">[380]</a></sup> In April 2005, MTV announced plans to broadcast a reality show around the lives of Serena and Venus, which was eventually aired on <a href="/wiki/ABC_Family" class="mw-redirect" title="ABC Family">ABC Family</a>. Williams has appeared twice on MTV's <i><a href="/wiki/Punk%27d" title="Punk'd">Punk'd</a></i> and in 2007, appeared in the <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> reality television series <i><a href="/wiki/Fast_Cars_and_Superstars:_The_Gillette_Young_Guns_Celebrity_Race" title="Fast Cars and Superstars: The Gillette Young Guns Celebrity Race">Fast Cars and Superstars: The Gillette Young Guns Celebrity Race</a></i>. In 2002, she played <i>Miss Wiggins</i> in the season 3 episode "Crouching Mother, Hidden Father" of <i><a href="/wiki/My_Wife_and_Kids" title="My Wife and Kids">My Wife and Kids</a></i>;<sup id="cite_ref-382" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-382">[381]</a></sup> she has also guest-starred in episodes of <i><a href="/wiki/The_Bernie_Mac_Show" title="The Bernie Mac Show">The Bernie Mac Show</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/ER_(TV_series)" title="ER (TV series)">ER</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Law_%26_Order:_Special_Victims_Unit" title="Law &amp; Order: Special Victims Unit">Law &amp; Order: Special Victims Unit</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-383">[382]</a></sup> In 2007, Williams appeared in the music video of "I Want You" by the American rapper <a href="/wiki/Common_(rapper)" title="Common (rapper)">Common</a>, alongside performers <a href="/wiki/Alicia_Keys" title="Alicia Keys">Alicia Keys</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kanye_West" title="Kanye West">Kanye West</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-384">[383]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In late 2009, Williams became the first active female professional athlete to appear in a <a href="/wiki/Feminine_hygiene" title="Feminine hygiene">feminine hygiene</a> product advertising campaign. A series of online videos and print advertisements for <a href="/wiki/Tampax" title="Tampax">Tampax</a> Pearl <a href="/wiki/Tampon" title="Tampon">tampons</a> showed her hitting balls at <a href="/wiki/Mother_Nature" title="Mother Nature">Mother Nature</a>, played by <a href="/wiki/Catherine_Lloyd_Burns" title="Catherine Lloyd Burns">Catherine Lloyd Burns</a>, to prevent Mother Nature giving her a red-wrapped gift, representing her <a href="/wiki/Menstrual_period" class="mw-redirect" title="Menstrual period">menstrual period</a>. In the online videos, the two have dueling press conferences over the "bad blood" between them. "A lot of celebrities are not open to working with our brand, and we're thrilled that Serena is", said a <a href="/wiki/Brand_manager" class="mw-redirect" title="Brand manager">brand manager</a> for Tampax at <a href="/wiki/Procter_%26_Gamble" title="Procter &amp; Gamble">Procter &amp; Gamble</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-tampon_ad_NYT_story_385-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-tampon_ad_NYT_story-385">[384]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In July 2012, she appeared in the <a href="/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company" title="American Broadcasting Company">ABC</a> comedic improv television series <i><a href="/wiki/Trust_Us_with_Your_Life" title="Trust Us with Your Life">Trust Us with Your Life</a></i> and as a lawyer on the <a href="/wiki/Lifetime_(TV_network)" title="Lifetime (TV network)">Lifetime</a> television series <i><a href="/wiki/Drop_Dead_Diva" title="Drop Dead Diva">Drop Dead Diva</a></i>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p>
      <p>To celebrate the 35th anniversary of <a href="/wiki/Pac-Man" title="Pac-Man">Pac-Man</a>, Williams made a cameo appearance in the movie <i><a href="/wiki/Pixels_(2015_film)" title="Pixels (2015 film)">Pixels</a></i>, which starred Adam Sandler and Kevin James, and premiered on July 24, 2015.<sup id="cite_ref-Pixels_386-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Pixels-386">[385]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams is known to be close to <a href="/wiki/Beyonc%C3%A9" title="Beyoncé">Beyoncé</a> and made a cameo appearance dancing in Beyoncé's music video for the song <i><a href="/wiki/Sorry_(Beyonc%C3%A9_song)" title="Sorry (Beyoncé song)">Sorry</a></i> in the hit album <i><a href="/wiki/Lemonade_(Beyonc%C3%A9_album)" title="Lemonade (Beyoncé album)">Lemonade</a></i>. Williams said the director told her, "We would love for you to be in this particular song. It's about strength and it's about courage and that's what we see you as."<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-387">[386]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Language_fluency">Language fluency</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=37" title="Edit section: Language fluency">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>In addition to English as her <a href="/wiki/Native_language" class="mw-redirect" title="Native language">native language</a>, Williams also speaks conversational French, and knows some Spanish and Italian. At the 2013, 2015, 2016 and 2018 <a href="/wiki/French_Open" title="French Open">French Open</a> she gave her on-court interviews in French, much to the crowd's delight.<sup id="cite_ref-USAToday-speaking-French_388-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-USAToday-speaking-French-388">[387]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-NYTimes-speaking-French_389-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-NYTimes-speaking-French-389">[388]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Miami_Dolphins_venture">Miami Dolphins venture</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=38" title="Edit section: Miami Dolphins venture">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>In August 2009, Williams and her sister Venus became minority owners of the <a href="/wiki/Miami_Dolphins" title="Miami Dolphins">Miami Dolphins</a> after purchasing a small stake in the team. They live near each other in Palm Beach Gardens, Florida,<sup id="cite_ref-voguesept17_248-4" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-voguesept17-248">[248]</a></sup> which is about an hour's drive from the Dolphins' stadium. They are the first Black women to hold any amount of ownership in an NFL franchise.<sup id="cite_ref-390" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-390">[389]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Charity_work">Charity work</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=39" title="Edit section: Charity work">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>In 2004 and 2005, Serena and her sister, Venus, visited hospitals and played several tennis matches in predominantly black cities in order to raise money for the local Ronald McDonald House charities. An ESPN episode was dedicated to the Williams sisters' charity tour.<sup id="cite_ref-ReferenceC_376-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-ReferenceC-376">[375]</a></sup> In 2008, as part of the Serena Williams Foundation's work, Williams helped to fund the construction of the Serena Williams Secondary School in <a href="/wiki/Makueni_County" title="Makueni County">Matooni, Kenya</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-391" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-391">[390]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-392" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-392">[391]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-393" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-393">[392]</a></sup> The Serena Williams Foundation also provides university scholarships for underprivileged students in the United States. In 2016, the Serena Williams Fund partnered with Helping Hands Jamaica to build the Salt Marsh Primary School for Jamaican youth in <a href="/wiki/Trelawny_Parish" title="Trelawny Parish">Trelawny Parish</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-394" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-394">[393]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-395" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-395">[394]</a></sup> She received a Celebrity Role Model Award from Avon Foundation in 2003 for work in breast cancer.<sup id="cite_ref-396" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-396">[395]</a></sup> Williams has also been involved in a number of clinics at schools and community centers, particularly those which have programs focusing on at-risk youth.<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_profile_1-10" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_profile-1">[1]</a></sup> She has also won the "Young Heroes Award" from Big Brothers Big Sisters of Greater L.A. and Inland (2003) and the "Family Circle and Prudential Financial Player Who Makes a Difference Award" (2004).<sup id="cite_ref-WTA_profile_1-11" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-WTA_profile-1">[1]</a></sup> In response to the <a href="/wiki/2010_Haiti_earthquake" title="2010 Haiti earthquake">2010 Haiti earthquake</a>, Williams, along with other ATP and WTA stars, decided to forgo their final day of preparation for the <a href="/wiki/2010_Australian_Open" title="2010 Australian Open">2010 Australian Open</a> to form a charity event in which all proceeds would go to the Haiti earthquake victims.<sup id="cite_ref-397" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-397">[396]</a></sup> Serena, along with her sister Venus, is a supporter and contributor of First Serve Miami, a foundation for youth who want to learn tennis but are socially and economically challenged.<sup id="cite_ref-398" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-398">[397]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-399" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-399">[398]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-400" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-400">[399]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-401" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-401">[400]</a></sup> She has been an <a href="/wiki/List_of_UNICEF_Goodwill_Ambassadors" title="List of UNICEF Goodwill Ambassadors">International Goodwill Ambassador</a> with <a href="/wiki/UNICEF" title="UNICEF">UNICEF</a> since 2011 and has helped launch UNICEF's Schools for Asia campaign.<sup id="cite_ref-402" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-402">[401]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-403" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-403">[402]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-404" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-404">[403]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-405" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-405">[404]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In addition to the Serena Williams Fund in 2016, Serena and Venus collaborated on the Williams Sisters Fund to work on philanthropic projects together.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_406-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-406">[405]</a></sup> Also in 2016, in their native home of <a href="/wiki/Compton,_California" title="Compton, California">Compton, California</a> Serena and Venus teamed up to found the Yetunde Price Resource Center, in honor of their late sister. The Resource Center provides services to families affected by community violence.<sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_406-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-406">[405]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Williams's return to Indian Wells in 2015 was done in partnership with the <a href="/wiki/Equal_Justice_Initiative" title="Equal Justice Initiative">Equal Justice Initiative</a>, a non-profit organization that provides legal representation to those who might have been denied a fair trial.<sup id="cite_ref-407" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-407">[406]</a></sup> EJI executive director <a href="/wiki/Bryan_Stevenson" title="Bryan Stevenson">Bryan Stevenson</a> lauded her courage in supporting his organization. "It's so rare when athletes at the top of their game are willing to embrace a set of issues that, for a lot of people, are edgier", he said. "This is not aid to orphans. ... She was standing when a lot of her contemporaries remain seated, speaking up when others are being quiet."<sup id="cite_ref-SPOTY15_408-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-SPOTY15-408">[407]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2014, Williams began hosting an annual charity run named "The Serena Williams Ultimate Fun Run". The event is in support of the Serena Williams Fund, which helps underprivileged individuals and communities that are affected by senseless violence and to ensure equal access to education of youth.<sup id="cite_ref-409" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-409">[408]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-autogenerated1_406-2" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-autogenerated1-406">[405]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-410" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-410">[409]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>In 2017, Williams became Ambassador for the <a href="/wiki/Allstate" title="Allstate">Allstate Foundation</a>'s Purple Purse project, an initiative to provide financial empowerment to domestic abuse victims.<sup id="cite_ref-411" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-411">[410]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-mediapost1_412-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mediapost1-412">[411]</a></sup> In a press release, Vicky Dinges, Allstate's senior vice president of corporate responsibility, said, "we are thrilled to welcome Serena, a longtime advocate and role model for so many, to the Purple Purse family. Her voice will bring new audiences into this critical conversation."<sup id="cite_ref-mediapost1_412-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-mediapost1-412">[411]</a></sup> </p>
      <p>Other charitable organizations Williams supports include the <a href="/wiki/Elton_John_AIDS_Foundation" title="Elton John AIDS Foundation">Elton John AIDS Foundation</a>, <a href="/wiki/Great_Ormond_Street_Hospital" title="Great Ormond Street Hospital">Great Ormond Street Hospital</a>, Hearts of Gold, the Common Ground Foundation, the Small Steps Project, the <a href="/wiki/HollyRod_Foundation" title="HollyRod Foundation">HollyRod Foundation</a>, Beyond the Boroughs National Scholarship Fund, World Education, the Eva Longoria Foundation, the Caliber Foundation and the Cure for MND Foundation.<sup id="cite_ref-413" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-413">[412]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-414" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-414">[413]</a></sup> </p> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Writing">Writing</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=40" title="Edit section: Writing">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <p>The Williams sisters, with author Hilary Beard, wrote a book titled <i>Venus &amp; Serena: Serving From The Hip: 10 Rules For Living, Loving and Winning</i>, which was published in 2005.<sup id="cite_ref-Hilarybeard.com_415-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Hilarybeard.com-415">[414]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-416" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-416">[415]</a></sup> During the <a href="/wiki/2009_Wimbledon_Championships" title="2009 Wimbledon Championships">2009 Wimbledon Championships</a>, Williams said that she was in the process of writing a TV show storyline, which would be converted into script form by her agency. She stated that the show would represent subject matter from a mix of popular American television shows such as <i><a href="/wiki/Desperate_Housewives" title="Desperate Housewives">Desperate Housewives</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Family_Guy" title="Family Guy">Family Guy</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-417" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-417">[416]</a></sup> Williams released her first solo autobiography, entitled <i>On the Line</i>, following the <a href="/wiki/2009_US_Open_(tennis)" title="2009 US Open (tennis)">2009 US Open</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2019)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup> </p> 
      <h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Career_statistics">Career statistics</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=41" title="Edit section: Career statistics">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h2> 
      <div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">
       Main article: 
       <a href="/wiki/Serena_Williams_career_statistics" title="Serena Williams career statistics">Serena Williams career statistics</a>
      </div> 
      <h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Grand_Slam_tournament_performance_timeline">Grand Slam tournament performance timeline</span><span class="mw-editsection"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a href="/w/index.php?title=Serena_Williams&amp;action=edit&amp;section=42" title="Edit section: Grand Slam tournament performance timeline">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></h3> 
      <table border="1px" style="border-collapse:collapse; border-color:#aaa; margin-bottom:0.5em;" cellpadding="5" cellspacing="0"> 
       <caption style="text-align:left">
        <b>Key</b> 
       </caption>

        <tr> 
         <td style="background:#00ff00"><b><abbr title="Won tournament">W</abbr></b> </td> 
         <td style="background:#D8BFD8">&nbsp;<abbr title="Reached final">F</abbr>&nbsp; </td> 
         <td style="background:yellow"><abbr title="Reached semifinal">SF</abbr> </td>

      <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886047268">.mw-parser-output .refbegin{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul{list-style-type:none;margin-left:0}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>ul>li,.mw-parser-output .refbegin-hanging-indents>dl>dd{margin-left:0;padding-left:3.2em;text-indent:-3.2em;list-style:none}.mw-parser-output .refbegin-100{font-size:100%}</style>
      <div class="refbegin" style="">
       (W) Won; (F) finalist; (SF) semifinalist; (QF) quarterfinalist; (#R) rounds 4, 3, 2, 1; (RR) round-robin stage; (Q#) qualification round; (A) absent; (NH) not held. SR=strike rate (events won/competed) 
      </div>

        To avoid confusion and double counting, these charts are updated at the conclusion of a tournament or when the player's participation has ended.

         <td style="text-align:left;"><span class="nowrap"><a href="/wiki/Australian_Open" title="Australian Open">Australian Open</a></span> </td> 
         <td style="background:#afeeee;"><a href="/wiki/1998_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="1998 Australian Open – Women's Singles">2R</a> </td> 
         <td style="background:#afeeee;"><a href="/wiki/1999_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="1999 Australian Open – Women's Singles">3R</a> </td>

         <td style="background:#ffebcd;"><a href="/wiki/2001_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2001 Australian Open – Women's Singles">QF</a> </td> 
         <td>A </td> 
         <td style="background:lime;"><a href="/wiki/2003_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2003 Australian Open – Women's Singles"><b>W</b></a> </td> 
         <td>A </td> 
         <td style="background:lime;"><a href="/wiki/2005_Australian_Open_%E2%80%93_Women%27s_Singles" title="2005 Australian Open – Women's Singles"><b>W</b></a> </td>

      <p><small>Note: <i>Williams withdrew from the 2018 French Open before her fourth round match, which does not officially count as a loss.</i></small> </p>
